main-text.text: INTRODUCTION
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: SWORDS & WIZARDRY: WHITEBOX is a fantasy role-playing game. The rules are extremely short compared to most modern games. Yet, this game contains within itself the soul of mythic fantasy and the kindling of wonder. The game is powerful because it's encapsulated by such a small formula-like a genie imprisoned in the small compass of an unremarkable lamp. This game serves as a good introduction for those learning how to play fantasy games, and is the ultimate tool for the expert Referee who customizes worlds with variant rules (as it's always easier to add rules than to untangle them away).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: And remember, with SWORDS & WIZARDRY: WHITEBOX, you are free to publish your own adventures, house-rules, and any other sort of materials designed for this game. Guidelines and requirements are at the end of the book.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: - Matthew J. Finch
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Like an archaeologist unearthing ancient ruins, my task was to uncover and preserve the very essence of what made role-playing so great during the genesis of the hobby. These rules are designed to maintain the spirit and philosophy of the oldest of gaming models, back in the days where rules weren't supposed to be "complete"-because half of the fun was making up your own!
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: I have been playing role-playing games since 1975, when I first discovered a fun game in a little white box, and I enjoy giving the reader of this book the opportunity to discover the flavor of what I found so many decades ago. I would like to thank Matthew Finch for giving me the opportunity to do this, Jason Cone for his wonderful suggestions, and, to quote Sir Isaac Newton: "If I have seen further it is only by standing on the shoulders of giants."
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: - Marv Breig
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: CHAPTER 1: GETTING STARTED
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: SWORDS & WIZARDRY: WHITEBOX requires two kinds of participants: (1) The Referee and (2) the Player. For Players, the first step in playing the game is to create a Player Character (PC). This is a simple matter of rolling some dice to determine your character's strength and other basic attributes, picking a character class, and buying in-game equipment. If you're the Referee, however, you've got a bit more preparation to do-that's covered in Chapter 7.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Rule Number One: The most important rule in SWORDS & WIZARDRY: WHITEBOX is that the Referee always has the right to modify the rules. In fact, it's encouraged! This is your game, after all. There are gaps in the rules-holes left open on purpose-because much of the fun of "old school" gaming is being able to make up rules as needed.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 8 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Dice
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Swords & Wizardry: WhiteBox uses several different types of dice, and they are abbreviated herein according to the number of sides they have. For example, a four-sided die is noted as "d4." If this text requires a player to roll "3d4" that means to roll three (3) four-sided dice and add the results together. Other die types (six-sided, eight-sided, ten-sided, twelve-sided, and twenty-sided) follow in the same manner.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: When asked to roll d100, roll two (2) ten-sided dice, treating the first roll as the "tens" and the second as the "ones." So, if one were to roll a "7" and then a "3", the result would be "73."
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The roll of two zeroes is treated as a result of "100," so you cannot roll a "0" on percentile dice. The lowest result possible is a "1."
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: character SheetS
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: A character sheet is a piece of paper designed to organize and contain any and all necessary PC information, for the benefit of both the Referee and Player. For WHITEBOX, the character sheet could be something as simple as a 3x5" index card-with equipment and spells written on the back:
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: attribute ScoreS
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: The basic abilities are numbers which represent the Strength, Intelligence, Wisdom, Constitution, Dexterity, and Charisma of a character. The standard way to create attribute scores is to roll 3d6 for each attribute in the previously mentioned order. Once those rolls have been made, it is often obvious which type of character best fits the abilities-though, the player always has the option to play any class desired. Once the player decides on a class, points from other attributes may be shifted around, but only into the "Prime Attribute" of that character class (Prime Attributes are discussed later). Shifting points around may not lower another ability score below 9, however.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: STR
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: INT
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: WIS
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: CON
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: DEX
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: CHR
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Some Referees allow more flexibility. One example is to let the players roll 3d6 a total of six times and arrange the rolls however they want. This allows the player to put the best results into abilities that best suit the type of character the player wants to be. There are several house rules that can be invented for this later on, if you choose.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: GettinG Started - 9
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: experience bonuS (xp)
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Each character gets a bonus percentage to their "experience points" (XP) that will increase the amount of experience points gained during an adventure. All characters add together the following: 5% if the character's Prime Attribute is 15+, 5% if Wisdom is 15+, and 5% if Charisma is 15+. A Cleric with Wisdom of 15+ gets the 5% bonus twice: once because it is the Prime Attribute for a Cleric, and again because it is applied to all characters. The maximum attainable bonus is 15%. All awards of XP to the character during play will be increased by the amount of the bonus (by 0%, 5%, 10%, or 15%, whichever it is).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: An alternate method for the experience point bonus is simply to give the character a bonus of 10% if the Prime Attribute is 15+, 5% if the Prime Attribute is 13-14, and -10% if the Prime Attribute is lower than 9. There is no bonus for scores between 9 and 12. If you use this method, do not also give the +5% bonuses described in the basic rules that follow: if you do it this way, the maximum XP bonus is 10%.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Strength (STR)
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Strength represents the character's physical power. It is the Prime Attribute for Fighters, so when a Fighter character has Strength of 15+, the character gets a 5% bonus to XP.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Intelligence (INT)
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Intelligence represents IQ, reasoning, and the ability to solve puzzles or understand difficult concepts. A high Intelligence score gives a character an additional language for every point above 10. Intelligence is the Prime Attribute for Magic-users, who will get a 5% bonus to XP if the character's Intelligence is 15+.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Wisdom (WIS)
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Wisdom determines a character's insight, perception, and good judgment. Wisdom is the Prime Attribute for Clerics. Any character with a Wisdom score of 15+ gets a 5% bonus to XP, and a Cleric character with Wisdom 15+ gets another 5% (total of 10%) because it is the Prime Attribute for the Cleric class.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Constitution (CON)
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Constitution refers to the health and endurance of a character. A high Constitution score (15+) gives the character a +1 to each hit die, and a low score (6 or lower) gives a -1 penalty to each hit die.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Dexterity (DEX)
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Dexterity is a combination of coordination and quickness. A high Dexterity score (15+) gives a character a bonus on "to-hit" rolls when attacking with a bow or other ranged weapon, and a low score (8 or less) gives a penalty of -1 to such rolls.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 10 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Charisma (CHR)
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Charisma refers to a character's leadership ability. Any character with a Charisma of 15+ receives a 5% bonus to XP.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Charisma also determines the number of Non-Player Character (NPC) hirelings a character can acquire. These hirelings include specialists (ship captains, assassins, etc.) and non-human creatures, but do not usually include basic men-at-arms. Charisma modifies the loyalty of these NPCs (See "Loyalty").
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Charisma Bonus Table
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Hiring Assistants
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Many characters, particularly when first starting an adventuring career, are in need of hirelings to assist in carrying loot or fighting monsters. Characters are free to create advertisements and inquire at local establishments to find available hirelings. The table below assumes that a typical adventure lasts roughly one week. Prices are in gold pieces.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Hiring Assistants Table
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: These rates are for humans only. Demi-humans cost more to hire-and it may take more than just the promise of gold coins.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: GettinG Started - 11
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Alternate Rule: Universal Attribute Bonus
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Swords & Wizardry: WhiteBox doesn't give many bonuses for having high attribute scores. You can modify the game to increase the effect that these scores have. One quick way to do this is to use the table below whenever you need a quick rule. Feel free to tinker with the values, if you even decide to even use them at all! For example, if you prefer the "average" range to be 9-12, adjust the table accordingly.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Universal Attribute Bonus Table
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Here are some examples of how the table can be used (and these are only options, not rules):
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Strength
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Fighters can use their Strength Bonus to modify their "to-hit" and damage results when using melee weapons.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Intelligence
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Magic-users can use their Intelligence Bonus to improve "spell effectiveness" (i.e. target suffers a penalty on saving throws).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Wisdom
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Clerics can use their Wisdom Bonus to improve "spell effectiveness" in the same way Magic-users use their Intelligence Bonus.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Dexterity
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Dexterity can be used to modify a character's Armor Class. This may be limited to more swashbuckling campaigns or in games where armor is more limited.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Be careful with this, though, unless you want to create super-hero characters!
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 12 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: hit pointS (hp)
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Hit points (HP) represent the amount of "damage" a character can take before dying: they are determined by the number of hit dice (HD) the character has at each level, which is found in the description of each character class later on. If a player begins the game with a 1st level Fighter (1+1 HD) the player would therefore roll 1 HD (1d6) and add "+1" to the end result to determine the PC's starting hit points. When the character accumulates enough XP to gain a level, usually a new hit die is rolled and added to the total (sometimes a new level only gives an additional hit point, though, not a whole new hit die).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Hit points are (optionally) re-rolled each time a Player Character gains a level. If the reroll results in the character having fewer hit points for the new level than from the old level, the hit points remain the same.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: alignment (al)
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Alignments in the game are described as Law, Chaos, and Neutrality. In general, Law also corresponds to being "good," Chaos corresponds to being "evil," and Neutrality simply means that the character is indifferent between the two moral polarities. It is quite possible for the Referee to make the alignment system more complex: perhaps Lawful only means that you are in favor of centralized hierarchies in society, in which case you could actually be Lawful Evil as well as Lawful Good. It is a matter of preference if you want to make the alignment system more complex.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Starting golD
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Roll 3d6 and multiply the result by 10. This represents the number of gold pieces (gp) that a character possesses at the start of the campaign.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: character retirement
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: If a character reaches the highest level listed on the table for that character class, what happens? Does advancement stop? Does the character have to retire? Each group has its own play style and a preference for a given range of character levels for their games. If the Referee wants to extend the tables to allow higher-level characters, then go for it!
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: GettinG Started - 13
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: CHAPTER 2: CHARACTER CLASSES
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: There are three character classes in the game: the Cleric, the Fighter, and the Magic-user. The Referee is, of course, free to invent or allow other character classes in the game.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: THE CLERIC
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Clerics are armored priests who serve a particular alignment, religion, or patron deity. Players may make up the details if the Referee doesn't use a particular mythology for the campaign. Mythologies and other details of a campaign world often come later if the Referee is just starting.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Regardless of the details, the Cleric is a champion of their faith and/or moral alignment. The character might be a sinister witch-hunter, an exorcist of demons, a shining knight of the faith, or a secret agent of some temple hierarchy. Since many of the Cleric's abilities are oriented toward healing and protecting, they tend to play a support role during combat. However, they are able to stand shoulder-to-shoulder with the party's Fighters if need be-at least for a while. Clerics must be either Lawful (good) or Chaotic (evil). There are no Neutral Clerics unless the Referee decides otherwise. Chaos, Law, and Neutrality are described further on.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Cleric Advancement Table
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: 14 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Cleric Class Abilities
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Weapon and Armor Restrictions:
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Because Clerics are forbidden the shedding of blood, they may only use blunt weapons (club, flail, mace, etc.) and the only missile weapon they are allowed is oil. Clerics have no armor restrictions.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Spell Casting: Clerics cast divine spells from a specific spell list, as per the Cleric Advancement table. Each day, the Cleric prays for a certain set of spells, choosing any spells from the standard list. Clerics of specific gods might have entirely different sets of spells as designed by the Referee, but the standard Cleric uses the standard spell list.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: S aving Throw : Clerics receive a +2 bonus on saving throws vs. poison and paralysis (unless the alternative "Saving Throw Matrix" is used).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Banishing Undead : Clerics can use their holiness to "Turn" the undead, causing them to flee (See Turning Undead, Page 22).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Establish Temple : At tenth level, a Cleric who chooses to build and dedicate a temple to a deity may attract a body of loyal followers who swear fealty to the character. If the Cleric changes alignment after establishing a Temple, the character will lose any followers (and probably face a mutiny).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Experience Bonus for Wisdom:
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Wisdom is the Prime Attribute for Clerics. Clerics with Wisdom of 15 or higher receive a 10% to experience, 5% as normal, and 5% because it is the Prime Attribute for the class.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: CharaCter ClaSSeS - 15
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: THE FIGHTER
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: The Fighter is a warrior, trained in battle and in the use of armor and weapons. Your character might be a ferocious Viking raider, a roaming samurai, or a medieval knight. Because they are the best equipped of all the character classes to dish out and absorb damage, Fighters often end up on the front lines, going toe-to-toe with dragons, goblins, and evil cultists. If you are the party's Fighter, the down-and-dirty work is up to you.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Fighter Advancement Table
main-text.name: Caption

main-text.text: 16 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Fighter Class Abilities
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Weapon and Armor Restrictions:
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Fighters are trained in warfare and, as such, have no restrictions on the kind of weapons or armor they can use.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Combat Machine: Against foes of one hit dice (HD) or fewer, Fighters get one attack per level each combat round.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Saving Throw: Fighters receive a +2 bonus on saving throws vs. death and poison (unless the alternative "Saving Throw Matrix" is used).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Establish Stronghold: At ninth level, a Fighter who chooses to build a castle is considered to have reached the rank of "Baron" or "Baroness," bestowed by the local ruler or monarch. The character may choose to attract a body of menatarms, who will swear their fealty as loyal followers.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Experience Bonus for Strength:
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Strength is the Prime Attribute for Fighters, which means that a Strength score of 15+ grants an additional 5% experience.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: CharaCter ClaSSeS - 17
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: THE MAGIC-USER
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: The Magic-user is a mysterious figure, a student of arcane powers and spell casting. They can be devastating opponents. However, at lower levels, they are quite vulnerable and must be protected by the other party members. As Magic-users progress, they generally become the most powerful of the character classes-holding sway over the political destinies of great kingdoms and able to create wondrous magical artifacts.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Magic-User Advancement Table
main-text.name: Caption

main-text.text: 18 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Magic-user Class Abilities
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Weapon and Armor Restrictions:
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Magic-users tend to spend their waking hours in study of arcane tomes and scrolls. As such, they have little time to train with weapons or learn how to properly engage in physical combat. Magic-users may only wield daggers or staves, and are not allowed the use of armor.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Spell Casting: Unlike the Cleric, the Magic-user owns a book of spells- which does not necessarily include all of the spells on the standard lists. Reading from this book, the Magic-user presses a select spell formula into memory, effectively "preparing" it to be cast. Once a prepared spell is cast, the spell formulae disappears from the Magic-user's mind, and must be prepared again before another attempt can be made to cast it. However, it is possible to prepare a spell multiple times using the available "slots" in the Magic-user's memory. If a Magic-user finds spell scrolls during an adventure, they can copy them into their spell book.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Saving Throw: Magic-users receive a +2 bonus on saving throws vs. spells- including those cast from wands and staves (unless the Alternate "Saving Throw Matrix" is used).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Experience Bonus for Intelligence:
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Intelligence is the Prime Attribute for Magic-users, which means that an Intelligence score of 15+ grants them an additional 5% to all experience points awarded.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: CharaCter ClaSSeS - 19
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: CHAPTER 3: CHARACTER ANCESTRY
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: In a fantasy world, humans often aren't alone. Elves may populate the great forests, Dwarves may carve their halls and mines into the heart of the earth, and Halflings may reside in the comfortable hill-houses of their bucolic shires. By contrast, some fantasy worlds depict an isolated humanity pitted against ancient pre-human evils and the grim, savage wilderness of worlds at the dawn (or dusk) of human civilization itself. Some fantasy worlds, as a third example, accentuate the bizarre, with a wide variety of fantasy species available to the players-such worlds are filled with conflict and contradictions, always with a new wonder to be found beyond the next corner. The Referee determines what non-human ancestries, if any, you can choose for your character.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: THE DWARF
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Dwarves tend to grow up in underground cities. As such, Dwarves easily take note of certain features of stonework: sloping corridors, moving walls, and traps made of stone (in particular: falling blocks, rigged ceilings, and tiny slits designed to release arrows, darts, or poison gas). There are no established rules or die roll for making use of these abilities; exactly what the Dwarf does or does not perceive is for the Referee to decide.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Fighting Giants: Giants, ogres, and similar giant-type creatures such as trolls are not good at fighting dwarves, and only inflict half the normal damage against them.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 20 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Dwarven Abilities
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Character Advancement: The only character class available to Dwarves is that of the Fighter, and they are typically allowed to advance only as high as 6th level.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Weapon and Armor Restrictions: Like human Fighters, Dwarves have been trained in warfare and have no restrictions on the weapons or armor they may use.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Keen Detection: Dwarves are good at spotting traps, slanting passages, and construction while underground.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Saving Throw: Dwarves do not use magic and, as such, are somewhat immune to its effects; they receive a +4 bonus on saving throws vs. magic (whether or not the alternate "Saving Throw Matrix" is used).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Languages: For campaigns that give each ancestry its own dialect, Dwarves should be able to speak with gnomes, goblins, orcs, and kobolds.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: THE ELF
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: The Referee can interpret Elves in many different ways. Are they faerie-folk of Irish legend, the Vanir of Norse mythology, or perhaps something more akin to the Elves of Tolkien's imagination?
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: As a baseline, most Elves are associated with magic as well as being skilled with the sword and bow. The Elven adventurer may choose, on any given day-perhaps when the moon rises-whether to use the capabilities of the Fighter or Magic-user. As a result, the Elf has two alternate advancement paths (experience points, hit dice, saving throws, "to-hit" bonuses, etc.) depending upon whether they donned steel that day or summoned up the power to cast spells.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Elves must use a spell book to prepare spells, just as a Magic-user. Spells disappear from the Elf 's casting capability once they are cast, until prepared again.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Elven Abilities
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Character Advancement: Elves may use either the Fighter or Magic-user class advancement charts, to be announced at the start of an adventure. They are typically allowed to progress only to 4th level as Fighters and 8th as Magic-users.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Weapon and Armor Restrictions:
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: When an Elf adventures as a Magic-user, the character has the same weapon and armor limitations as a Magic-user. The exception to this would be magic armor, which may still be worn even when the Elf is acting as a Magic-user.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Hereditary Foes: Elves gain an extra +1 ("to-hit" or to damage) when fighting goblins, orcs, intelligent undead, and lycanthropes. Elves are also immune to paralysis caused by undead such as ghouls.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Keen Detection: Elves are good at spotting hidden and concealed doors (1-4 on a d6 when searching, 1-2 on a d6 if just passing by). Languages: For campaigns that give each ancestry its own dialect, Elves should be able to speak with gnolls, goblins, orcs, and hobgoblins.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: CharaCter anCeStry - 21
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: THE ELF (VARIANT)
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Some Referees may want to allow the Elf to advance as a blend of Fighter and Magic-user instead of switching back and forth. In that model, the following advancement table might be used instead. Aside from Character Advancement and Weapon and Armor Restrictions, the abilities of the Elven Ancestry remain the same.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Elf (Variant) Advancement Table
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Elven Abilities (Variant)
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Weapon and Armor Restrictions: Elves would have the advantage of both magic and armor at the same time, so the Referee may limit the Elf to chain mail. Elves may not use two-handed weapons (two-handed sword, polearms, etc.) or shields while casting spells.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 22 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: THE HALFLING
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Halflings are short, often stout, and live in shires, rustic communities that are usually remote from those of larger folk. A few of them have a mildly adventurous spirit, enough to venture forth for a while at least, exploring the world beyond the farms and fields of the local shire.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Fighting Giants: Giants, ogres, and similar giant-type creatures such as trolls are not good at fighting small creatures such as halflings and dwarves, and only inflict half the normal damage against them.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Halfling Abilities
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Character Advancement: The only character class available to Halflings is that of the Fighter, and they are typically allowed to advance only as high as 4th level.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Weapon and Armor Restrictions: Like human Fighters, the Halfling has no weapon or armor restrictions.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Deadly Accuracy with Missiles:
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Halflings receive a +2 "to-hit" when firing missile weapons in combat.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Near Invisibility: When not engaged in combat, Halflings can be quite stealthy, making themselves hard to spot and moving in almost total silence.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Saving Throw: Halflings are somewhat immune to magic, and receive +4 on saving throws vs. magic (even if the "Saving Throw Matrix" is used).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Languages: For campaigns that give each ancestry its own dialect, Halflings should be able to speak with creatures that fit the style of the Referee's campaign.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: CharaCter anCeStry - 23
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: CHAPTER 4: ITEMS & EQUIPMENT
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Each character starts with some gold pieces (3d6x10) at the beginning of the game, used to buy equipment. One gold piece (gp) is worth 10 silver pieces (sp) or 100 copper pieces (cp). Prices for equipment are listed on the tables below in amount of gold pieces. The Referee is encouraged to include additional items and equipment.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Equipment Weight
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: A "normal" level of miscellaneous equipment is assumed to weigh 10 pounds. If treasure is added to this, each coin and gem is assumed to weigh 0.1 pound.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Adventuring Gear
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: 24 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Transportation
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Melee Weapons
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: * Two-handed weapon
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: â  Can be used as either a one-handed or two-handed weapon
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: â¡ Can be used as either a melee or missile weapon
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: itemS & equipment - 25
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Missile Weapons
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: * Rate of Fire is the number of projectiles than can be fired per combat round
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: â  There is a +2 "to-hit" bonus for missile weapons utilized at short range (x1), a +1 "to-hit" bonus at medium range (x2), and no bonus or penalty for long range (x3) attacks
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: In the Original Game, all weapons did 1d6 damage, regardless of type. Swords & Wizardry WhiteBox provides some slight variation. To play the Original Game as it was written, simply ignore all variations in weapon damage - they all inflict 1d6 damage regardless of whether the weapon is a two-handed sword or a dagger.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 26 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Armor
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: * At the Referee's discretion, magical armor weighs either half of its normal weight or nothing at all
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: calculating armor claSS
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: To calculate a character's Armor Class, you must decide which system to use. The two systems have the same numbers, but in one of them a high armor class is better, and in one a low armor class is worse. Just decide which you prefer:
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Descending AC System
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: In this system, an unarmored human has an AC of 9. The armor you buy lowers your AC and the lower the AC, the harder you are to hit. To calculate your Armor Class, look at the Armor table above, in the "Effect onâ¦" column. For whatever type of armor you bought, subtract the number shown from your base AC of 9. That's your new Armor Class.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Ascending AC System
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: For the ascending system, an unarmored person has an AAC of [10]. AAC means "ascending armor class," and it is used in brackets as a reminder of which system is in use. Your armor adds to your AAC, so the higher your AAC, the harder it is for your enemies to hit you. To calculate your Ascending Armor Class, look at the Armor table on the previous page, in the "Effect onâ¦" column. For whatever type of armor you bought, add the number shown in brackets to your base AAC of [10]. That's your new Armor Class.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: converting armor claSS SyStemS
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: To translate between the Ascending and Descending AC systems, the ascending armor class (AAC) and descending armor class (AC) values should add up to 19. Thus, AC 7 is the same as AAC [12] (19-7=12).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The Referee must decide which of the two armor class systems to use. In the "Descending" armor class system, a lower AC means you are harder to hit. In the "Ascending" armor class system, it is a higher armor class that is harder to hit.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Numbers for the "Ascending" armor class system always appear in brackets [like this].
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: itemS & equipment - 27
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: CHAPTER 5: PLAYING THE GAME
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Once characters have been created, the Referee will describe where the characters are and what they can see. The game might start in a rural peasant village, a vast and teeming city spiked with towers and minarets, a castle, a tavern, or at the gates of an ancient tomb. From that point on, Players describe what their characters do. Going down stairs, attacking a dragon, talking to other Player Characters (PCs) or Non-Player Characters (NPCs) controlled by the Referee -all of these kinds of actions are decided by the players. The Referee then describes what happens as a result: the stairs lead down to a huge tomb, the dragon attacks the characters, etc. The rules below are guidelines handling events like combat, gaining experience, movement, healing, dying, and other important parts of the game.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Basically, you and the Referee work together, with the Referee handling the details of a dangerous fantasy world, and you handling what your character does in it. The epic story of your character's rise to greatness (or death in the effort) is yours to create in the Referee's world.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: gaining experience
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Characters are awarded Experience Points (XP) for killing monsters and accumulating treasure. Monsters have set Experience Point values in their descriptions, and one gold piece acquired is equal to one XP. Experience is awarded for accumulating treasure because every gold piece gained by a character is an index of the player's skill. Awarding experience only for killing monsters fails to reward a party of adventurers that successfully lures a dragon away from its hoard so that its treasure can be stolen without a fight- it fails to reward characters that operate by intelligence, stealth, trickery, and misdirection.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Each character class has a Prime Attribute listed in its description, and the character creation process details how to determine the character's total XP bonus. There are two different ways of doing it, but each one results in a percent bonus. If a character's bonus is 10%, for example, and the Referee awards 1000xp to each character, that particular character would get 1100xp (10% of 1000 is 100, so the character gets a bonus of 100xp).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: time
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: The Referee will be required to make general rulings on the passage of time during the course of a campaign (e.g. "A few hours later...") and should be governed by common sense. There are, however, two important time measurements that merit brief definitions--the "turn" and "combat round." A turn (lasting ten minutes) is used to track and measure actions, movement and resources when our intrepid adventurers are in dangerous places. The shorter combat round (lasting one minute) is used in the midst of battle to allow for a faster blow-by-blow account of the action.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 28 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: movement
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Base movement rate for all ancestries is calculated on the table below in tens of feet per turn, allowing for two moves per turn.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Movement Rate
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Movement Rate Adjustments
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: combat
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: When the party of adventurers comes into contact with enemies, the order of events in the combat round is as follows:
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 1) The Referee determines if one side or the other is entitled to a free attack or move as a result of surprise-this is either a judgement or a die roll of some kind, depending on the circumstances. Normally, anyone is surprised if they roll a 1 or a 2 on a d6. In a random encounter, distance is 2d4 x10ft (underground) and 2d4 x10 yards aboveground.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 2) Determine initiative. One roll is made for each side, not for each individual in combat.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Â· Party with initiative acts first (missile fire, casting spells, movement, melee attacks, etc.) and results take effect.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: Â· Party that lost initiative acts; results take effect.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: Â· The round is complete; keep turn order for the next round if the battle has not been resolved.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: playinG the Game - 29
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: how initiative workS
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: At the beginning of the first combat round, each side rolls initiative on a d6- high roll wins. The winning side acts first, casting spells, moving, and attacking. The other side takes damage and casualties, and then has its turn.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Initiative rolls may result in a tie. When this happens, both sides are considered to be acting simultaneously. The Referee may handle this situation in any way they choose-with one caveat. The damage inflicted by the combatants during any simultaneous initiative is inflicted even if one of the combatants dies during the round. It is possible for two combatants to kill each other in this situation. If you want to play things more simply, just reroll initiative if there is a tie until one side or the other wins the initiative.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Some Referees prefer to have all parties make a " statement of intent " before they roll initiative in order to force players to decide what they're doing before they know who goes first.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Alternate Combat Sequence
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: The sequence of battle is one of the most commonly house-ruled parts of the game. Here is one possibility, also based on the Original Game:
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 1) Roll for surprise . Anyone not surprised gets a free round of combat in the normal order (see below). If neither side, or both sides, are surprised, move on to the next step. In a random encounter, distance is 2d4 x10ft (underground) and 2d4 x10 yards aboveground.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 2) Roll for initiative (one roll for each whole side), and follow the sequence described:
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: First, any "prepared" spells are cast. It takes a full combat round to prepare a spell, but one can be prepared ahead of time. Spellcasters who won the initiative cast their spells first. They may then start preparing a spell for the next round, if desired.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Next, missile weapons are fired (if the bow was already in the character's hands and ready to go). This also happens in order of initiative.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Then melee combat takes place, in order of initiative. Finally, movement takes place, in order of initiative.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: If it is important to find out which character in the party goes before another one, just compare their Dexterity scores to see which is higher.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 30 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: the attack roll
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: The most important rule to understand about combat is the attack roll. To attack with a weapon, the player rolls a d20 and adds any bonuses to the result. These "to-hit" bonuses may include a strength bonus (for attacks with hand held weapons), a dexterity bonus (for attacks with missile weapons), and any bonuses for magic weapons. The player then subtracts any "to-hit" penalties they might have from their roll.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The attack roll is then compared to a table to see if the attack hits. If the attack roll is equal to or higher than the number on the table, the attack hits. If you are using the Ascending AC system, rather than refer to these tables, there is a quick formula presented at the end of this chapter that you can use (See Ascending AC Combat, Page 23). The Referee decides which will be used.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: If an attack hits, it inflicts damage (as determined by the weapon's damage die). The damage is subtracted from the defender's hit point total (See "Damage and Death").
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Cleric Attack Rolls
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: playinG the Game - 31
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Fighter Attack Rolls
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Magic-user Attack Rolls
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: 32 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: SPECIFIC SITUATIONS
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: The following are a compilation of guidelines and instructions for handling certain, specific situations that might arise during combat.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Damage anD Death
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: When a character (or creature) is hit, the amount of damage taken is deducted from their hit points. When hit points reach 0, the character dies.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: A Less Harsh Method
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Referees have different ideas concerning how lethal a game should be. For this reason, many allow characters to become "unconscious" at 0 HP, with death staved off until the character reaches some predetermined negative number.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: For example, many Referees employ a house rule which allows a character's HP to fall below 0 by as many points as their level before the character dies; a 4th level character might die only if they fall below -4 HP. Generally, though, a character with fewer than 0 HP is considered to be bleeding to death at 1 HP per round until the wounds are bound up.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: healing
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: In addition to the various magical means of restoring HP, a character will recover 1 full hit point per day of uninterrupted rest. Four weeks of rest will restore all of a character's HP-
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: regardless of how many the character lost.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Binding Wounds
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Referees can allow characters to bind 1d4 HP worth of wounds following a battle. This is of particular use in low-magic campaigns or in adventures where none of the Players has chosen to run a Cleric.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Note that the character can only recover HP lost during this particular battle. Recovered HP cannot cause a character to have more hit points than normal.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: playinG the Game - 33
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: inviSible opponentS
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: An invisible opponent can only be attacked if its general location is known, and the attack suffers a -4 penalty "to-hit." Note that more powerful monsters (those with sensitive smell, hearing, or those with more than 6 HD) will frequently be able to detect invisible opponents; the Referee should determine the chance of this based on the creature and the situation.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: melee attack
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: A melee attack is an attack with a hand-held weapon such as a sword, spear, or dagger. Two combatants within ten feet of each other are considered to be "in melee."
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: miSSile attack
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Missile attacks are attacks with ranged weapons such as crossbows, slings, or thrown axes. When using missiles to fire into melee, it is not possible to choose which opponent (or friend!) will receive the brunt of the attack.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: morale
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Certain monsters, such as mindless or undead creatures, are fearless and will always fight to the death. The majority, however, will not continue to fight a hopeless battle and will seek to retreat, surrender, or flee. The Referee will decide when monsters abandon battle and retreat, based upon the situation and the monster's intelligence. Referees should also use morale to determine the actions and loyalty of hirelings or other companion NPCs.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: negotiation anD Diplomacy
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Some combats can be averted with a few well-chosen words (even lies). If the party is outmatched, or the monsters don't seem likely to be carrying much in the way of loot, the party might elect to brazen their way through in an attempt to avoid combat or at least delay it until more favorable conditions arise.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: SpellS
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell casting begins at the start of the combat round. It is possible to prepare a spell while within melee range of an opponent (10 feet) but if the caster suffers damage while preparing a spell, the spell is lost. Unless stated otherwise, the spell is cast (takes effect) in the caster's initiative phase. Note that in the Alternative Sequence of Combat (described above), spell casting works differently. In that system, it takes a full round to prepare a spell, the spell is cast at the beginning of the round before anything else happens, and the caster may spend the rest of the round preparing a new spell (or doing something else such as moving or even fighting).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 34 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: loyalty
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: The Referee may wish to make "loyalty checks" for NPCs put into dangerous situations or ones offered bribes to change sides during a conflict. When a loyalty check is made, roll 3d6 and consult the Loyalty table for the result. Remember that these checks can be modified by a Player's Charisma score.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Good treatment, respect, and a fair share of treasure earned should garner bonuses to loyalty checks, while abuse, physical or otherwise, will bring about penalties, abandonment, or worse. NPCs should be treated as distinct individuals, and not mere extensions of the Player Character.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Loyalty Table
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Saving throwS
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: From time to time, a spell or some other kind of hazard requires you to make a "saving throw." A successful saving throw means that the character avoids a threat or lessens its effect. Each character class has a saving throw target number which gets lower and lower as the character gains levels. To make a saving throw, roll a d20. If the result is equal to or greater than the character's saving throw target number, the saving throw is successful. Monsters can also make saving throws (their saving throw target number is their HD subtracted from 19).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: playinG the Game - 35
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Alternate Rule: The Saving Throw Matrix
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: The Swords & Wizardry saving throw system is an adaptation of the original, which had several categories of different risks instead of a single basic saving throw as used here. The original version had the following categories and target numbers:
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Saving Throw Categories (Alternate Method)
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: This table does not integrate directly into Swords & Wizardry: if you were to houserule it in, you would have to eliminate the Swords & Wizardry class bonuses on saving throws (i.e., the bonuses listed for each class in the class description but not racial bonuses for non-humans).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: *Legal Note: The information in this sidebar is provided for purposes of comparison, and is not to be construed as an indication respecting compatibility with any trademark.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 36 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: turning the unDeaD
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Lawful clerics (only) have the ability to "turn" the undead, causing them to flee or destroying them outright. When a turning attempt is made, roll 3d6 and consult the Turning Undead table (see below) for the result.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: If the result on the dice is equal to or greater than the number shown on the table, all undead creatures of the targeted type are turned and will flee for 3d6 rounds (or cower helplessly if they are unable to flee).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: For Lawfully aligned Clerics, if the table indicates a "D" then the undead creature is destroyed automatically and will crumble to dust.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Turning Undead Table
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Turn Undead (Variant)
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Referees who wish to limit the use of the Turn Undead ability might decide to count this as merely a 1st level Cleric spell.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Chaotic Clerics and the Undead
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Many Referees allow Chaotic clerics as well as Lawful clerics to turn the Undead. If Chaotic clerics are allowed to turn the undead, treat a result of "D" on the table a bit differently; instead of destroying the undead creature, the Chaotic cleric has forced it into servitude. It will follow the character's commands, although the Referee will decide the limitations on this power. Perhaps the cleric can only keep a certain number of undead under control at one time (or a certain number of hit dice) - the cleric's level is a good number to use for this limit, whether it stands for a maximum number of Undead creatures or for a maximum number of total hit dice.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: playinG the Game - 37
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Ascending AC Combat - Quick Method
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: If you're using the Ascending AC system, it may be easier to calculate your "to-hit" rolls according to a simple formula. The numbers are the same as the Descending AC tablesthis is just a different way of calculating the results.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Here's how it's done:
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: To attack with a weapon, the player rolls a d20 and adds any bonuses to the result. These "to-hit" bonuses now include the character's Base "to-hit" Bonus, as shown on the table below, and may include a strength bonus (for attacks with handheld weapons), a dexterity bonus (for attacks with missile weapons), and any bonuses for magic weapons. The player then subtracts any "to-hit" penalties they might have from their roll. If the result is equal to or greater than the opponent's Ascending AC, the attack hits.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Ascending AC Combat Table (Quick Method)
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Note: This quick system only works for the ascending AC system.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: In order to use this system, you'll need to write down your Base "to-hit" Bonus, and adjust it as you gain levels, but after doing that, you won't have to check the table to see if you score a hit. All you need to know is whether the total result was equal to or higher than the target's armor class.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 38 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: GAMEPLAY EXAMPLE
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: A Fighter, Arnold the Lion, is fighting three goblins in a dark alley of the Glittering City of Semoulia. We eavesdrop just as the encounter begins:
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Arnold's player: "I draw myself up to full height and inform them that I'm a captain of the guard. My soldiers are right behind me, and these vermin better disperse or I'll have them brought in for interrogation."
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Referee: "Um, no. They're not buying it. You're covered in filth from that garbage pit."
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Arnold's player: "Oh, yeah. I forgot that."
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Referee: "Roll initiative." (Secretly rolls a d6 and gets a result of 6.)
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Arnold's player : "I rolled a 2."
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Referee: "The goblins attack first. They're all more than ten feet from you, and they move forward with their clubs at the ready."
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Arnold's player: "They don't charge?"
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Referee: "Nope."
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Arnold's player: "They don't get an attack because they closed in. It's my turn to attack, right?"
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Referee: "Yes."
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Arnold's player: (Rolls a d20.) "16-sweet! Adding my base to-hit bonus and Strength bonus gives me a total 'to-hit' roll of 18!"
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Referee: (Notes that goblins have an Armor Class of 14, using the ascending AC rules.) "You swing your sword into the leading goblin. Roll for damage."
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Arnold's player: (Rolls a d6.) "2 points, but I've got a +1 damage bonus, so that's a total of 3 damage."
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Referee: (That's enough to kill it. The goblin had only 2 hit points.) "Okay, so as it's moving forward, the goblin slips a little bit in a puddle on the stones of the narrow alley where you're fighting, and skids right onto your sword. As you yank out the blade, the goblin falls dead to the ground. The other two are still attacking, but they look nervous now-obviously starting to reconsider this whole thing."
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: REMEMBER
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: SWORDS & WIZARDRY is a free-form roleplaying game, meaning that there aren't very many rules. The Referee is responsible for handling situations that aren't covered by the rules, making fair evaluations of what the characters do and deciding what happens as a result. This is not a game in which the players are "against" the Referee, even though the Referee is responsible for creating tricky traps, dangerous situations, and running the monsters and other foes the PCs will encounter during the game. In fact, the players and the Referee cooperate with each other to create a fantasy epic, with the Referee creating the setting and the players developing the story of the heroes. If they aren't skillful and smart, the epic might be very short. But it's not the Referee's job to defeat the players-it's their job to provide interesting (and dangerous) challenges, and then guide the story fairly.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: playinG the Game - 39
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: CHAPTER 6: SPELLS & MAGIC
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Clerics and Magic-Users can cast spells, Fighters cannot. Spells have three phases. First they are memorized (a character can only memorize a certain number of spells to bring along on an adventure - see the description of the character classes to find out how many, and what level). Second, they are prepared, which is the process of saying the magic words and making the magic gestures. Third, the spell is cast, which means it takes effect and the magic happens. In the normal sequence of combat, the caster starts preparing at the beginning of the round and casts the spell whenever their side has the initiative. In the alternative combat sequence, it takes a whole round to prepare a spell, but spells are cast at the beginning of the next round, and the caster can then take other actions during the round, including preparing a spell for the next round.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: SPELL DESCRIPTIONS
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Contained herein are all of the Cleric and Magic-user spells, in alphabetical order. The chaotic-version spells in parentheses are available to Clerics only, not Magic-users.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Alter Time
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M3 Range: 240 ft. Duration: 30 min.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The caster must announce which of the two options is being cast. Both options have a 60 foot radius area of effect:
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 1. As a Haste spell, as many as 24 creatures may move and attack at double normal speed.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 2. As a Slow spell, as many as 24 creatures failing a saving throw may only move and attack at half speed.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: Animal Growth
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M5 Range: 120 ft. Duration: 2 hours
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This spell causes 1d6 normal creatures to grow immediately to giant size. The affected creatures can attack as per a giant version of the normal animal.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 42 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Animate Dead Spell Level: M5 Range: Referee's discretion Duration: Permanent
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This spell animates skeletons or zombies from dead bodies. 1d6 undead are animated (per level of the caster above 8th). The corpses remain animated until destroyed or dispelled.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Anti-Magic Shell
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M6 Range: Caster Duration: 2 hours
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: An invisible bubble of force surrounds the caster, impenetrable to magic. Spells and other magical effects cannot pass into or out of the shell.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Bless (Curse)
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: C2 Range: Target PC or NPC (out-of-combat) Duration: 1 hour
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The caster must announce which of the two options is being cast. The recipient of this spell cannot be in combat when it is cast.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: As a Bless spell, the recipient is granted a +1 bonus to all attack rolls and, if the target is not a Player Character, improves overall morale.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: As a Curse spell, the recipient is cursed with a -1 penalty to all attack rolls and, if the target is not a Player Character, suffers a decrease to morale.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Charm Monster
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M4 Range: 60 ft. Duration: Until dispelled
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This spell operates in the same manner as Charm Person, but can affect more powerful monsters. Up to 3d6 monsters of fewer than 3 HD are affected.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Charm Person
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M1 Range: 120 ft. Duration: Until dispelled
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This spell affects living bipeds of human size or smaller, such as goblins or dryads. If the spell succeeds (saving throw allowed), the unfortunate creature falls under the caster's influence.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Cloudkill
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M5 Range: Close Duration: 1 hour
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Foul and poisonous vapors boil from the thin air, forming a cloud 15 feet in radius. The cloud moves away from the caster at a rate of 6 feet per minute unless its direction or speed is affected by winds. Unusually strong gusts can dissipate and destroy it. Poison-laden, the horrid mist is heavier than air, and thus sinks down any pits or stairs in its path. This spell affects only creatures with 5 or fewer HD.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: SpellS & maGiC - 43
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Commune
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: C5
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Range: Caster Duration: 3 questions
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Higher powers grant answers to three questions the caster poses. Higher powers don't like being constantly interrogated by mere mortals, so the spell should be limited to one casting per week or so. The Referee may rule that a caster may cast a double strength Commune spell composed of six questions once per year.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Confusion
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M4 Range: 120 ft. Duration: 2 hours
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This spell confuses people and monsters, making them act randomly. The effects of the confusion may shift every 10 minutes or so, and the dice are rolled again to determine any change. Roll 2d6 to determine the creature's behavior:
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Confusion Reaction Table
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: The spell affects 2d6 creatures, plus an additional creature for every caster level above 8th. Creatures of 3 HD or fewer are automatically affected by the spell, and it takes effect immediately. Creatures of 4 HD or more automatically resist the confusion effect until it reaches its full power, which takes a number of minutes equal to 1d12 minus the caster's level. These creatures must make a saving throw when the effect reaches full power and every 10 minutes thereafter or become confused for the remainder of the spell's duration.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Conjure Elemental
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M5 Range: 240 ft. Duration: Until dispelled
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The caster summons a 16 HD elemental (any kind) from the elemental planes of existence, and binds it to the caster's commands. Each type of elemental may only be summoned once per day. The elemental obeys the caster only for as long as the caster concentrates on it; when the caster ceases to concentrate, even for a moment, the elemental is released and will attack.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 44 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Contact Other Plane
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M5 Range: None Duration: See table
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The caster creates a mental contact with the planes, forces, powers, and geometries of the beyond, in order to gain affirmative or negative answers to questions the caster contemplates. The spell's effect depends on how deeply the caster wishes to delve into the planes of existence.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Contact Other Plane
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: * Planes are the "depth" at which the caster chooses to seek the truth; number of Yes/No questions asked.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: â  Temporary insanity lasts for as many weeks equal to the depth of the plane where the caster's sanity failed.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: â¡ This represents the possibility of being misled or misinterpreting an answer.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Control Weather
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M6
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Range: Referee's discretion
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Duration: Referee's discretion
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The caster can summon or stop rainfall, tornadoes, create unusually high or low temperatures, clear the sky of clouds or summon clouds into being.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Create Food and Drink
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: C5
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Range: Close
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Duration: Instantaneous
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This spell creates a one-day supply of simple food and drinking water for 24 humans (or horses, which drink the same amount as a human for game purposes).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: SpellS & maGiC - 45
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Crystal Ball Spell Level: M3 Range: 60 ft. Duration: 2 hours
main-text.name: Caption

main-text.text: The caster must announce which of the two options is being cast. A two foot thickness of solid stone or a thin layer of lead blocks both options.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 1. As a Clairaudience spell, the caster can hear through solid obstacles.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 2. As a Clairvoyance spell, the caster can see through solid obstacles.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Cure (Cause) Disease Spell Level: C3 Range: Touch Duration: Instantaneous
main-text.name: paragraph

main-text.text: 1. As a Cure Disease spell, the recipient is cured of all diseases- including those magically inflicted.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 2. As a Cause Disease spell, the recipient is inflicted with a disease to be determined by the Referee.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: Cure (Cause) Light Wounds
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: C1 Range: Touch Duration: Instantaneous
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 1. As a Cure Light Wounds spell, the caster cures 1d6+1 HP.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 2. As a Cause Light Wounds spell, the caster causes 1d6+1 damage.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: Cure (Cause) Serious Wounds
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: C4 Range: Touch Duration: Instantaneous
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 1. As a Cure Serious Wounds spell, the caster cures 3d6+3 HP.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 2. As a Cause Serious Wounds spell, the caster causes 3d6+3 damage.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 46 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Darkvision
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M3
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Range: Touch Duration: 1 day
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The recipient of the spell can see in total darkness. The recipient should roll 1d6 on the table on the following page to determine the range of the vision.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Darkvision Range
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Death Spell
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M6 Range: 240 ft. Duration: Permanent
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Within a 60 foot radius, up to 2d8 creatures with fewer than 7 HD perish.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Detect Chaos (Law)
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: C1, M2 Range: 120 ft. (C), 60 ft. (M) Duration: 1 hour (C), 20 min. (M)
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 1. As a Detect Chaos spell, the caster detects creatures of Chaos, or those with chaotic enchantments, intentions, thoughts, or auras within the spell's range. Poison is not inherently evil or chaotic and cannot be detected by means of this spell.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 2. As a Detect Law spell, the spell works exactly like Detect Chaos except that it detects L aw.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: Detect Invisibility
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M2 Range: 10 ft./caster level Duration: 1 hour
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Caster can perceive invisible creatures and objects.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: SpellS & maGiC - 47
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Detect Magic
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: C1, M1 Range: 60 ft. Duration: 20 min.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The caster can perceive in places, people, or things the presence of a magical spell or enchantment. Magical items or secretly placed charms may be discovered with this spell.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Detect Thoughts (ESP)
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M2 Range: 60 ft. Duration: 2 hours
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The caster can detect the thoughts of other beings. The spell cannot penetrate more than two feet of stone and is blocked by even a thin sheet of lead.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Dimensional Portal
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Dimensional Portal is a weak form of the Teleport spell that can be managed by lesser magicians. The caster can teleport themselves, an object, or another person with perfect accuracy to the stated location, as long as it is within the spell's given range.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 48 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Disintegrate
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M6 Range: 60 ft. Duration: Permanent
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The caster defines one specific target such as a door, a peasant, or a statue, and it disintegrates into dust. Magical materials are not disintegrated, and living creatures (such as the aforementioned peasant) are permitted a saving throw. The Disintegrate spell cannot be dispelled.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Dispel Chaos (Law)
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: C5 Range: 30 ft. Duration: 10 min. (on magic items)
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 1. As a Dispel Chaos spell, the spell is similar to the arcane spell Dispel Magic, but works against items, spells, or agents of Chaos. However, unlike Dispel Magic, this spell also functions against chaotic sendings, possibly including dreams or supernatural hunting-beasts.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 2. As a Dispel Law spell, the spell works exactly like Dispel Chaos, except that it will dispel L aw.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: Dispel Magic
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M3 Range: 120 ft. Duration: 10 min. (on magic items)
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Dispel magic can be used to completely dispel most spells and enchantments. As an example of how one might referee this spell, the chance of dispelling magic could be a percentage based on the ratio of the level of the caster trying to dispel over the level of the caster (or HD of the monster) who hurled the original magic.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Thus, a 6th level Magic-user attempting to dispel a charm cast by a 12th level Magic-user has a 50% chance of success (6 / 12 = 1/2). If the 12th level Magic-user were dispelling the 6th level Magic-user's charm, the dispelling caster's chance of success would be 200% (12 / 6 = 2).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Feeblemind
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M5
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Range: 240 ft.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Duration: Permanent until dispelled
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Feeblemind is a spell that affects only Magic-users. The saving throw against the spell is made at a -4 penalty, and if the saving throw fails, the targeted Magic-user becomes feebleminded until the magic is dispelled.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Find Traps
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: C2 Range: 30 ft. Duration: 20 min.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Find Traps can allow the caster to perceive both magical and non-magical traps at a distance of 30 feet.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: SpellS & maGiC - 49
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Fireball
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M3
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Range: 240 ft.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Duration: Instantaneous
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: A missile shoots from the caster's finger to explode at the targeted location in a furnace-like blast of fire. It has a burst radius of 20 feet and damage is 1d6 per level of the caster. The blast shapes itself to the available volume. A successful saving throw means that the target only takes half damage.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Duration: 1d6 turns + 1 turn/level
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This spell grants the power of flight, with a movement rate of 120 feet per round. The Referee rolls for the duration of the spell in secret and does not disclose this information to the Player.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Hallucinatory Terrain
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M4
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Range: 240 ft.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Duration: Until touched by an enemy or dispelled
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This spell changes the appearance of the terrain into the semblance of what the caster desires. A hill can be made to disappear, or could be replaced with an illusory forest, for example.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 50 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Hold Monster
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M5
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Range: 120 ft.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Duration: 1 hour + 10 min./level
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The caster can target either 1d4 creatures (saving throw applies) or may instead target a single creature who must make their save at a -2 penalty.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Hold Person
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: C2, M3 Range: 180 ft. (C), 120 ft. (M) Duration: 90 min. (C), 1 hour + 10 min./level (M)
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The caster can target either 1d4 persons (with the same parameters as Charm Person; saving throw applies) or may instead target a single creature who must make their save at a -2 penalty.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Hold Portal
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M1 Range: Referee's discretion Duration: 2d6 turns
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This spell magically holds a door or gate in position for the spell's duration (or until dispelled). Creatures with magic resistance can shatter the spell without much effort.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Insect Plague
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: C5 Range: 480 ft. Duration: 1 day
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This spell only works outdoors. A storm of insects gathers, and goes wherever the caster directs. The cloud is approximately 400 square feet (20 x 20 feet, with roughly corresponding height). Any creature with fewer than 2 HD exposed to the cloud of insects will flee in terror (no saving throw).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Invisibility
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M2 Range: 240 ft. Duration: Until dispelled or an attack is made
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The object of this spell, whether a person or a thing, becomes invisible to both normal vision and to darkvision. If the Referee is using the invisibility rules unchanged, the result is that an invisible creature cannot be attacked unless its approximate location is known, and all attacks are made at -4 to-hit.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: SpellS & maGiC - 51
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Invisibility, 10 ft. radius
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M3
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Range: 240 ft.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Duration: Until dispelled or an attack is made
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Identical to the Invisibility spell, which makes the target creature or object invisible to normal vision and to dark vision, except that it also throws a sphere of invisibility (with a 10 foot radius) around the recipient, which moves along with the target.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Invisible Stalker
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M6
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Range: Near Caster
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Duration: Until mission is completed
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This spell summons an Invisible Stalker with 8 HD. The stalker will perform one task as commanded by the caster, regardless of how long the task may take or how far the stalker may have to travel. The stalker cannot be banished by means of Dispel Magic; it must be killed in order to deter it from its mission.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Knock
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M2 Range: 60 ft. Duration: Instantaneous
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This spell unlocks and unbars all doors, gates, and portals within its range, including those held or locked by normal magic.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Levitate
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M2 Range: 20 ft./level Duration: 10 min./level
main-text.name: Text
