main-text.text: This spell allows the Magic-user to levitate, moving vertically up or down, but the spell itself provides no assistance with lateral movement. A wall, cliff side, or ceiling could be used to move along hand-over-hand. Levitation allows up or downward movement at a rate of up to 6 feet per minute (60 feet per turn), and the caster cannot levitate more than 20 feet per level from the ground level where the spell was cast (such range being applied both to movement into the air and to downward movement into a pit or chasm).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 52 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Light (Dark)
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: C1, M1 Range: 120 ft. Duration: 2 hours (C), 1 hour + 10 min./level (M)
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 1. As a Light spell, the caster targets a person or object which then produces a light about as bright as a torch with a radius of 20 feet.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 2. As a Dark spell, the caster instead causes night-time darkness to fall upon the area with a radius of 20 feet.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: Light (Dark), Continual
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: C3, M2 Range: 120 ft. Duration: Permanent until dispelled
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 1. As a Light, Continual spell, the caster targets a person or object which then produces a light about as bright as a torch with a radius of 20 feet.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 2. As a Dark, Continual spell, the caster instead causes night-time darkness to fall upon the area with a radius of 20 feet.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: Lightning Bolt
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M3 Range: 60 ft. Duration: Instantaneous
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: A nearly ten foot wide bolt of lightning extends 60 feet from the fingertip of the caster. Anyone in its path suffers 1d6 points of damage per level of the caster, though a successful saving throw halves damage. The bolt always extends 60 feet, even if this means that it ricochets backward from something that blocks its path.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Locate Object
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: C3, M2 Range: 90 ft. (C), 60 ft. + 10 ft./level (M) Duration: 1 min./level
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This spell gives the caster the correct direction (as the crow flies) toward an object the caster specifies with a description. The object cannot be something the caster has never seen, although the spell can detect an object in a general class of items known to the caster: stairs, gold, etc.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: SpellS & maGiC - 53
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Magic Jar
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M5 Range: See below Duration: See below
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This spell relocates the caster's life essence, intelligence, and soul into an object (of virtually any kind). The "jar" must be within 30 feet of the caster's body for the transition to succeed.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Once within the magic jar, the caster can possess the bodies of other creatures and people, provided that they are within 120 feet of the jar and fail a saving throw. The caster can return their soul to the magic jar at any time, and if a body they control is slain, the caster's life essence returns immediately to the jar. If the caster's body is destroyed while their soul is in the magic jar, the soul no longer has a home other
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: than within the magic jar (although the disembodied wizard can still possess other bodies as before). If the jar itself is destroyed while the Magic-user's soul is within, the soul is lost. The Magic-user can return from the jar to their own body whenever desired, thus ending the spell.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Massmorph
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M4 Range: 240 ft. Duration: Until negated or dispelled
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: One hundred or fewer human-sized creatures are changed to appear like innocent trees. The illusion is so perfect that creatures moving through the "forest" will not detect the deception.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Move Earth
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M6 Range: 240 ft. Duration: Permanent
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This spell can only be used above ground. It allows the caster to move hills and other raised land or stone at a rate of 6 feet per minute for 1 hour.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 54 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Move Water
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M6 Range: 240 ft. Duration: See below
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The caster must announce which of the two options are being cast:
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 1. The spell lowers the depth and water level of lakes, rivers, wells, and other bodies of water to 1/2 their normal levels. Used this way, the spell lasts for 10 turns.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 2. Alternately, this spell creates a gap through water, but only to a depth of 10 feet. Used this way, the spell lasts for 6 turns.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: Neutralize Poison
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: C4 Range: Referee's discretion Duration: 10 min.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This spell counteracts poison, but does not bring the dead back to life.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Passwall
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M5 Range: 30 ft. Duration: 30 min.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This spell creates a hole through solid rock. The hole or tunnel is up to 10 feet deep and is large enough to allow the passage of an average sized man.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Phantasmal Force
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M2 Range: 240 ft. Duration: Until negated or dispelled
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This spell creates a realistic illusion in the sight of all who view it. The illusion disappears when it is touched, but if the viewer believes the illusion is real they can take damage from it.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: SpellS & maGiC - 55
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Plant Growth
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M4 Range: 120 ft.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Duration: Permanent until dispelled
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Up to 300 square feet of ground can be affected by this spell; undergrowth in the area suddenly grows into an impassable forest of thorns and vines. The caster can decide the shape of the area to be enchanted. An alternate version (Referee's decision) would allow the spell to affect an area of 300 x 300 feet, for a total of 90,000 square feet.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Polymorph
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M4 Range: See below Duration: See below
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The caster must announce which of the two options are being cast:
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 1. The caster assumes the form of any object or creature, gaining the new form's attributes (the use of wings, for example), but not its hit points or combat abilities. The Referee might allow the benefit of the new form's armor class, if it is due to heavily armored skin. A great deal of the spell's effect is left to the Referee to decide. This form of the spell lasts for roughly one hour plus one additional hour for each level of the caster.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 2. Alternately, this spell allows the caster to turn another being into a different type of creature (such as a dragon, a garden slug, and of course, a frog or newt). The polymorphed creature gains all the abilities of the new form, but retains its own mind and hit points. Used in this way, the range on this spell is 60 feet. This form of the spell lasts until dispelled.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: Project Image Spell Level: M6 Range: 240 ft. Duration: 1 hour
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The caster projects their image to a maximum range of 240 feet. Not only does the projected image mimic the caster's sounds and gestures, but any spells cast will appear to originate from the image.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 56 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Protection from Chaos (Law)
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: C1, M1 Range: Caster only Duration: 2 hours (C), 1 hour (M)
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 1. As a Protection from Chaos spell, the caster creates a magical field of protection around themselves to block out all chaotic monsters, who suffer a -1 penalty "to-hit" against the caster, and the caster gains +1 on all saving throws against such attacks.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 2. As a Protection from Law spell, it does the same thing except that lawful creatures suffer the -1 penalty.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: Protection from Chaos (Law), 10 ft. radius
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: C4, M3 Range: 10 ft. radius around caster Duration: 2 hours
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 1. As a Protection from Chaos, 10 ft. radius spell, it has the same effect as Protection from Chaos-except that its effect covers an area rather than an individual.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 2. As a Protection from Law, 10 ft. radius spell, it has the same effect as Protection from Law-except that its effect covers an area rather than an individual.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: Protection from Normal Missiles
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M3 Range: 30 ft. Duration: 2 hours
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The recipient becomes invulnerable small non-magical missiles. Only normal missiles projected by normal weapons are affected.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Purify (Putrefy) Food and Drink
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: C1 Range: Close/Touch Duration: Instantaneous
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 1. As a Purify Food and Drink spell. the caster causes enough food and water for up to a dozen people to be made pure, removing spoilage and poisons.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 2. As a Putrefy Food and Drink spell. the caster causes enough food and water for up to a dozen people to be made putrid, creating spoilage and poisons.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: SpellS & maGiC - 57
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Quest
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: C5, M6
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Range: 30 ft. Duration: Until completed
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: If the victim fails a saving throw, the caster may set a task for the victim to perform, such as, "Find the Goblet of Morde and return here to tell me its location." If a Magic-user casts this spell the victim will die if they ignore the Quest altogether. If a Cleric casts this spell the victim's failure to obey will result in a curse to be determined by the Referee.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Raise Dead
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: C5 Range: Line of sight Duration: See below
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Raise Dead allows the Cleric to raise a corpse from the dead, provided it has not been dead too long. The normal time limit is 4 days, but for every caster level higher than 8th, the time limit extends another 4 days. Characters with low constitution might not survive the ordeal; and even for those with a strong constitution, a period of two weeks is required before they can function normally. This spell only functions on ancestries that can be used for Player Characters (i.e., "human-like").
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Read Languages
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M1 Range: Reading distance Duration: 1 or 2 readings
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This spell allows the caster to read directions, instructions, and similar notations that are written in unfamiliar or even unknown languages. It is especially useful for treasure maps.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Read Magic
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M1 Range: Caster only Duration: 2 scrolls or other writings
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This spell allows the caster to read magical writings on items and scrolls. Magical writing cannot be read without the use of this spell.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 58 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Reincarnation
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M6 Range: Touch Duration: Instantaneous
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This spell brings a dead character's soul back from the dead, but the soul reappears in a newly formed body of the same alignment as the deceased.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Remove Curse
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: C3, M4 Range: Close/Touch Duration: Instantaneous
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This spell removes one curse from a person or object.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Sleep
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M1 Range: 240 ft. Duration: Referee's discretion
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This spell puts enemies into an enchanted slumber (no saving throw is permitted). It can affect a number of creatures based on their hit dice.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Affected by Sleep
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Speak with Animals
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: C2 Range: 30 ft. Duration: 1 hour
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The caster can speak with animals within range. There is a chance that the animals will assist the caster and they will not attack the caster or the caster's party (unless the caster said something particularly offensive).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: runninG the Game - 59
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Speak with Plants
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: C4 Range: 30 ft. Duration: 1 hour
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The caster can speak to and understand the replies of plants. Plants will obey the caster's commands as far as they are able (e.g. twisting or bending aside to allow passage, etc.).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Sticks to Snakes
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: C4 Range: 120 ft. Duration: 1 hour
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The caster may turn as many as 2d8 normal sticks into snakes, each one having a 50% chance of being venomous. The snakes follow the caster's commands, but turn back into sticks at the end of the spell (or when killed).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Telekinesis M5
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Spell Level: Range: 120 ft. Duration: 1 hour
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The caster can move objects using mental power alone. The amount of weight the caster can lift and move is 20 pounds per level.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 60 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Teleport
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M5 Range: Touch Duration: Instantaneous
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This spell transports the caster or another person to a destination that the caster knows (at least knowing what it looks like from a painting or a map). Success depends on how well the caster knows the targeted location:
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 1. If the caster has only indirect experience of the destination (known only through a picture or map) there is a 25% chance of success- with failure resulting in death.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 2. If the caster has seen but not studied the destination there is an 20% chance of failure. Half of failures will place the traveler 1d10 x 10 feet below the intended location, possibly resulting in death from arrival within a solid substance. The other half of failures will place the traveler 1d10 x 10 feet above the targeted location, possibly resulting in a deadly fall.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 3. If the caster is familiar with the location or has studied it carefully there is a 5% chance of failure, with 1 in 6 failures arriving below and 5 in 6 arriving above the targeted location. In either case, the arrival is 1d4 x 10 feet low or high.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: Transform Rock-Mud
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M5 Range: 120 ft. Duration: 3d6 days, or spell reversal
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This spell transforms rock (and any other form of earth) into mud, or mud to rock. An area of roughly 300 x 300 feet becomes a deep mire, reducing movement to 10% of normal.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Transform Stone-Flesh
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M6 Range: 120 ft. Duration: Permanent until reversed
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This spell transforms flesh into stone or stone into flesh, as desired by the caster. A saving throw is permitted to avoid being turned into stone, but if the spell succeeds the victim is transformed into a statue.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: runninG the Game - 61
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Wall of Fire or Ice
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M4 Range: 60 ft. Duration: Concentration
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The caster must announce which of the two options are being cast:
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 1. As a Wall of Fire spell, the caster conjures a wall of fire that flares into being and burns for as long as the caster concentrates upon it. Creatures with 3 or fewer hit dice cannot pass through it, and no creature can see through it to the other side. Passing through the fire inflicts 1d6 hit points of damage (no saving throw) and undead creatures sustain twice the normal damage. The caster may choose to create a straight wall 60 feet long and 20 feet high, or a circular wall with a 15 foot radius, also 20 feet high.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 2. As a Wall of Ice spell, the caster conjures up a 6 foot thick wall of ice. The caster may choose to create a straight wall 60 feet long and 20 feet high, or a circular wall with a 15 foot radius, also 20 feet high. Creatures with 3 or fewer hit dice cannot affect the wall, but creatures of 4+ hit dice are able to smash through it, taking 1d6 points of damage in the process. Creatures with fire-based metabolisms take 2d6 instead of the normal 1d6. Fire spells and magical effects are negated in the vicinity of the wall.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: Wall of Stone or Iron
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M5 Range: 60 ft. Duration: Permanent (stone) or 2 hours (iron)
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The caster must announce which of the two options are being cast:
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 1. As a Wall of Stone spell, the caster conjures a wall of stone 2 feet
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: thick, with a surface area of 1,000 square feet.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 2. As a Wall of Iron spell, the caster conjures an iron wall from thin air.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The wall is 3 feet thick, with a surface area of 500 square feet.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Water Breathing
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M3 Range: 30 ft. Duration: 2 hours
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This spell grants the ability to breathe underwater until the spell's duration expires.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 62 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Web
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M2 Range: 30 ft. Duration: 8 hours
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Fibrous, sticky webs fill an area up to 10 x 10 x 20 feet. It is extremely difficult to get through the mass of strands-it takes one turn if a torch and sword (or a flaming sword) are used, and creatures larger than a horse can break through in 2 turns. Humans take longer to break through-perhaps 3 to 4 turns or longer at the Referee's discretion.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Wizard Eye
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M4 Range: 240 ft. Duration: 1 hour
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The caster conjures up an invisible, magical "eye," that can move a maximum of 240 feet from its creator. It floats along as directed by the caster, at a rate of 120 feet per turn.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Wizard Lock
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Spell Level: M2 Range: Close Duration: Permanent until dispelled
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: As with a Hold Portal spell, but it is permanent until dispelled. Creatures with magic resistance can shatter the spell without effort. Any Magicuser three levels or higher than the caster can open the portal, and a Knock spell will open it as well (although the spell is not permanently destroyed in these cases).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: runninG the Game - 63
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: CHAPTER 7: RUNNING THE GAME
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Running a game of SWORDS & WIZARDRY: WHITEBOX is a lot easier than running most other role-playing games, simply because there are not as many rules and your own discretion overrides them anyway. Most situations are handled by making "common sense" decisions concerning what happens next.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: For example, if there are a bunch of zombies around the next corner and the Players decide not to go around that corner, it's up to the Referee to determine whether or not it makes sense for the zombies to rush around the corner and attack-or whether their orders are to simply stay where they are. If a Player decides that the character is going to jump through a wall of fire, with several bottles of flammable oil in a backpack, it's up to the Referee to determine whether or not they explode.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This means "making up" a lot of stuff on the spot; it's a game with a lot of improvisation. If you're not a good storyteller or if you're not up to doing a lot of creative thinking on the fly, it might be better that you try a different game-one that provides more rules and guidance for every little situation that might arise. But if you're a good storyteller, creative and fair, SWORDS & WIZARDRY: WHITEBOX's small, Spartan rule-set frees up your creativity to create a fantasy role-playing experience completely different from the type of game that depends on a multitude of rules.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: SWORDS & WIZARDRY: WHITEBOX also frees up your creativity in terms of customizing the game. Unlike a more complex game, you can add house rules wherever you want to without accidentally messing up something else buried in the rules. If you want to use critical hits and fumbles, add 'em in. You won't break anything-there's not that much to break!
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: DeSigning an aDventure
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Basically, the "adventure" is just the setting for the game-usually a map and then notes about certain locations on that map. As the Players tell you where their characters go and what they do, you're referring to the map and your notes to describe what happens as a result. Don't try to plan for all contingencies-it's guaranteed that the players will do something unexpected during the adventure and you'll just have to roll with it, thinking on your feet and making up new things as you go. Just as you challenge the Players with adventure, they challenge you to keep up with their collective creativity.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: creating a campaign
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: A campaign is the world beyond the adventure-the cities, forests, coastlines, and kingdoms of the fantasy world. The players will almost certainly want their characters to explore the wilderness, visit cities, and do all sorts of things in the fantasy world. At the beginning of the game, you might want to sketch out a map of a single village (as the starting point) and some of the surrounding area. (The location of the first adventure-a dark forest, perhaps) As the players move their characters around from adventure to adventure, you can expand the little map into an entire fantasy world with the continents, kingdoms, and great empires at your disposal.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 64 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: If you want to take a shortcut, you can set your entire campaign in a fictional world created by the author of one of your favorite fantasy stories. Most of these have maps and the author has already created the details and feel of the world for you. For example, the worlds of Conan's Hyboria (Robert E. Howard), of Elric and the Eternal Champions (Michael Moorcock), and of the Dying Earth (Jack Vance) are popular fictional settings ready for gaming. Indeed, publishers have already created pre-packaged campaigns for all three of these examples.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: experience pointS
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Experience Points are awarded to Players for gaining treasure and killing monsters, as an earlier Player's section has described. It may seem counterintuitive that treasure somehow makes characters more experienced, but that's not what awarding experience for gold pieces is all about. Gold pieces are an after-the-fact measurement of how ingenious the character (Player) was in getting them. The gold pieces are not the source of the experience-they are the measurable product of it.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: That being said, there are many alterative ways for Referees to award XP. For example, active participation in the campaign might warrant experience for each hour of real-time play, as could solving puzzles and aiding allies. A particularly clever solution or epic victory might warrant double the normal XP amount awarded, while an abysmal failure might merit half. Some Referees make all earned Experience Points a part of a community total to be divided evenly, since not all the characters have the same opportunities in a given adventure. Others prefer a more competitive game, whereby each player earns XP according to individual accomplishments.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: If you find that whatever system you're using leads the players toward bad decisions-seeking out unnecessary combat or looking for traps to spring- you might consider adjusting your system. This is true for the "official" system of awarding experience as well. Remember, the Referee is the ultimate judge of what works best for a game and any rule can be changed to fit the group.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Scale of Advancement
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Referees all have their own style of campaign, and it would be silly for one author to impose needless restrictions on anyone playing the game. However, it is worth noting that this rules set was designed with the notion that 4th level characters are "heroic" and thus the tables were capped at level 10. A Referee who wishes to extend the tables to higher levels is encouraged to do so if it fits the style of the campaign.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: guiDelineS for running a Dungeon aDventure
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Random Monsters and Treasure
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: When randomly stocking a dungeon, you can use the following guidelines for placing treasure and monsters. For every room, roll 1d6. If the result is a 1 or 2, there is a monster present, and that monster has a 50% chance of having a treasure. For rooms that don't have a monster, there is still a 1 in 6 chance that there is a hidden treasure in the room.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: runninG the Game - 65
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Hidden Treasure
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Hidden Treasure is always hidden, and often guarded by a trap. At the very least, the treasure is hidden in a secret compartment (treat as a secret door). Keep in mind that secret doors require a lot of time for searching, and if the compartment is in a pillar or statue a player must state that they are searching (or, if an elf, the player must at least state that they are examining the thing before getting their automatic chance to detect a secret door).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Where Treasure is Hidden
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: 66 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Traps on Hidden Treasure
main-text.name: Caption

main-text.text: Type of Trap
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: runninG the Game - 67
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Alarm or Summons traps either sound a loud alarm which alerts wandering monsters to the area or (at higher levels) magically summons a guardian of the treasure. Such alarms might also occasionally be silent, to keep intruders unaware that their presence has been noted.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Individual Damage traps inflict roughly 1d6 hit points of damage per dungeon level. Thus, on level 2 you might find a 20ft deep pit trap or a scything blade that inflicts 2d6 points of damage.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Group Damage traps usually inflict roughly 1d6 points of damage per dungeon level to multiple people in a blast radius, but there is often a saving throw to cut the damage in half.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Individual Chance of Death traps usually involve a saving throw for the person who triggers the trap, but not to anyone else. These traps are usually poison, but can be anything that involves a saving throw, including sleep, disintegration, charm, and petrifaction.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Group Chance of Death traps are the same as Individual Chance of Death traps, but have an area of effect.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Other Dungeon Features
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Secret Doors: When the characters search a 10-foot area for one turn, each character has a 2-in-6 chance to find a secret door if there is one. Elves, however, have a 4-in-6 chance to find it and a 1-in-6 chance to notice it without even searching. Finding a secret door does not necessarily mean the characters know how to open it; they just know that it is there. The same rules apply for smaller-scale searches (such as checking a pillar for secret compartments), which require only half the time.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Listening at Doors: Listening at a door has a 1-in-6 chance of success for humans; nonhuman characters most likely have better hearing than humans and can hear noises with a 2-in-6 chance of success.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Opening Doors: Doors in a dungeon are stuck, and require a die roll of 1-2 on a d6 to force open. Multiple characters - up to a maximum of three - can smash through a door together, giving each one a separate, normal chance of success all at once. However, they spill into the room and should automatically lose initiative if there are monsters within. It is important to get the door open on the first try, because a failed attempt warns any monsters on the other side of the door that there is trouble. Monsters know their doors, and can go through them without difficulty.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 68 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Traps and Pits: In general, unless the Referee rules otherwise for a particular trap, anyone passing over or through the trigger for a trap has a 2-in-6 chance to spring it. It is suggested (but not required) that the Referee allow Dwarves to recognize traps involving stonework. Here is a starter rule that the Referee can modify as desired: For traps involving a stone trigger (such as a pressure plate) or a hole or gap in stonework (such as a falling block or an arrowhole), a Dwarf has a 1-in-6 chance to notice the features of a trap before passing over/through it, as long as movement is at a careful speed; the Dwarf has a 4-in-6 chance to notice features of a stonework trap when searching (one turn per 10-foot square of wall or floor). Identifying the features of a trap does not tell the dwarf how to disarm the trap, although in some cases the disarming mechanism might be obvious once the trap's visible features are identified. This rule treats stone traps for Dwarves in the same way that secret doors are treated for Elves.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Wandering Monsters: Each turn, there is a 1-in-6 chance that a wandering monster arrives (at the standard perception distance of 2d4 x10ft). Wandering monsters do not carry treasure.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: runninG the Game - 69
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Monsters on Dungeon Level 1
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Monsters on Dungeon Level 2
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: 70 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Monsters on Dungeon Level 3
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: runninG the Game - 71
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Monsters on Dungeon Level 4
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: 72 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Monsters on Dungeon Level 5
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: runninG the Game - 73
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Monsters on Dungeon Level 6
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Monsters on Dungeon Level 7
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: 74 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Monsters on Dungeon Level 8
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: runninG the Game - 75
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: CHAPTER 8: MONSTERS
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: There's not a lot of detail given about the monsters, because the more detail given, the more your own mental image of the fantasy world is going to be locked into a single track. We're not going to say that giant ants are red, nocturnal, three feet long, and fond of eating Elves. Because, in your mind, they might be blue, diurnal, five feet long, and eat only plants unless attacked. Details about monsters toss roadblocks in front of the imagination. Yes, details can also inspire imagination, but we're making the assumption that if you're interested in fantasy gaming in the first place, you've got a good imagination as-is and don't require details about the size of a giant ant.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: One important characteristic of all monsters, though, is that they can see in the dark.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The following is a quick reference guide for how to read monster descriptions:
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Armor Class
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: "Armor Class" is explained earlier in the rules for combat. If you're using the Descending AC system (where lower AC is better), disregard the numbers in brackets. If you're using the Ascending AC system (where a high AC is better), use the numbers in brackets.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Hit Dice
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: "Hit Dice" is the number of dice (d6) rolled to determine an individual creature's HP. If there is a plus or minus after the number, add or subtract that number once from the total rolled.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 76 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Attacks
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: "Attacks" lists the number of attacks a monster has and the damage they inflict. Most monsters have one attack and inflict 1d6 damage-there are, however, some exceptions.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Special
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: "Special" is just a "marker" of sorts for the Referee, a reminder that a monster has a special ability.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Move
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: "Move" is the monster's movement rate and is handled like it is for PCs.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Hit Dice Equivalent (HDE)
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: "Hit Dice Equivalent" is used to separate monsters into "difficulty levels" so that when creating an adventure the Referee has some guidelines concerning what characters can and cannot handle. Some monsters have multiple HDE's listed-this is because certain monsters have a range of hit dice. Order is always from lowest HD to highest HD.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Experience Points (XP)
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: "Experience Points" are presented after a monster's Hit Dice Equivalent (HDE) rating, and list the number of XP the adventuring party gains as a result of killing the creature. In some cases, however, the Referee may choose to award experience points for defeating a creature without killing it (circumventing it by creative means, capturing it to bring home, etc.). Some monsters have multiple Experience Points listed-this is because certain monsters have a range of hit dice. Order is always from lowest HD to highest HD.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Magic Resistance
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: "Magic Resistance" isn't one of the entries, but some creatures may have "magic resistance." The given percentage chance is the likelihood that any magic used against the creature (other than bonuses from weapons) will fail to take effect. To determine whether or not magic used will have an impact, roll a d100. The magic fails if the result is less than the given percentage.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Saving Throw
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: "Saving Throw" isn't one of the entries, but all creatures have a saving throw. It is the number on the d20 the monster needs to equal or exceed in order to avoid a threat or lessen its effect. It is found by subtracting the monster's HD from 19. For example, a monster with 4 HD has a saving throw of 15. Alternatively, a monster can simply be treated as a Fighter or whatever character class makes sense for that monster, with the monster's hit dice being used for its level.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: monSterS - 77
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Monster Attack Rolls
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Note
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: If you are using the quick formula for calculating attacks using the ascending armor class system, the monster's normal "to-hit" bonus is equal to its hit dice (capped at +15). For example, a monster with 3 HD attacks with a +3 "to-hit" bonus.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 78 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: MONSTER DESCRIPTIONS
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Contained herein are all of the monsters presented in alphabetical order.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: banShee
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 0 [19] Hit Dice: 7 Attacks: Claw Special: See below Move: 12 HDE/XP: 11/1,700
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Banshees are horrid fey (or undead) creatures that live in swamps and other desolate places. They can only be harmed by magical or silver weapons. Banshees have a 49% resistance to magic, and they are immune to enchantments. Their shriek (once per day) necessitates a saving throw versus death or the hearer will die in 2d6 rounds. They can travel over water and other terrain as if it were land, but crossing running water causes it to lose its magic resistance for 3d6 hours. They look like gaunt humans with long, stringy hair and glowing yellow eyes. They often wear hooded cloaks. At the Referee's discretion, such creatures might be undead rather than faerie-folk, and are considered to have 9 HD for turning purposes.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: baSiliSk
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Basilisks are great lizards whose gaze turns to stone anyone meeting its eye (fighting without looking incurs a -4 penalty "to-hit"). If the basilisk's own gaze is reflected back at it, it has a 10% chance to force the basilisk into a saving throw against being turned to stone itself.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: beetle, giant fire
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 4 [15] Hit Dice: 1+3 Attacks: Bite Special: None Move: 12 HDE/XP: 1/15
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: A giant fire beetle's oily light-glands glow red, and continue to give off light for 1d6 days after they are removed (shedding light in a 10 foot radius).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: monSterS - 79
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: black puDDing
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 6 [13] Hit Dice: 10 Attacks: Strike Special: Acidic Move: 6 HDE/XP: 11/1,700
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Black puddings are amorphous globs with an acidic surface. They are subterranean predators and scavengers. Any weapon or armor contacting a black pudding will be eaten away by the acid as follows: weapon (1 hit by weapon), chain mail or lesser armor (1 hit by pudding), plate mail (2 hits by pudding). If a weapon or armor is magical, it can take an additional hit per +1 before being dissolved. They are immune to cold and divide when attacked by lightning.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Blink dogs are pack hunters, intelligent and usually friendly to those who are not of evil intent. They can teleport short distances (without error) and attack in the same turn-in most cases (75%) a blink dog will be able to teleport behind an opponent and attack from the rear (with bonuses).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: These large, hairy, goblin-like humanoids are stealthier than their size would suggest, almost always getting the chance to surprise even the most alert opponents with a roll of 1-3 on a d6 (50% of the time).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 80 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: centaur
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 5 [14], 4 [16] w/ shield Hit Dice: 4 Attacks: Weapon or kick Special: None Move: 18 HDE/XP: 5/240
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Half man, half horse, centaurs are fierce warriors and well-known creatures of mythology. The Referee may choose any "version" of the centaur from folklore for the campaign: some are chaotic, some aloof, and some are soothsayers.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: centipeDe, giant (Small)
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 9 [10] Hit Dice: 1d2 HP Attacks: Bite Special: Poison (see below) Move: 13 HDE/XP: 2/30
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Giant lethal centipedes of the small size inflict a lethal amount of poison with each bite, but inflict no damage if the saving throw is successful (+4 modifier to opponent's saving throw).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: centipeDe, giant (meDium)
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 5 [14] Hit Dice: 2 Attacks: Bite Special: Poison (see below) Move: 15 HDE/XP: 4/240
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This man-sized giant centipede is a deadly predator with armored segments, a vicious bite, and a lethal (though relatively weak) poison (+6 modifier to opponent's saving throw).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: monSterS - 81
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: centipeDe, giant (large)
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 0 [19] Hit Dice: 4 Attacks: Bite Special: Poison (see below) Move: 18 HDE/XP: 6/400
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: A twenty-foot long horror of chitin, multiple legs, and clashing pincers dripping with venom (+6 modifier to opponent's saving throw).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: cockatrice
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 6 [13] Hit Dice: 5 Attacks: Bite Special: Bite turns bitten into stone Move: 6/18 (when flying) HDE/XP: 7/600
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Resembles a bat-winged rooster with a long, serpentine tail. Its bite turns enemies to stone unless a successful saving throw is made.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 82 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: chimera
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 4 [15] Hit Dice: 9 Attacks: Bite (equals # of heads) Special: Breathes fire, flies Move: 12/18 (when flying) HDE/XP: 11/1,700
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The chimera is a winged, three headed beast; one is the head of a goat, one the head of a lion, and one the head of a dragon. The dragon head can breathe fire (3 times per day) with a range of 50 feet, causing 3d8 damage to anyone caught within the fiery blast (saving throw for half damage).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Demons
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Demons are creatures of the lower planes of existence, but they are occasionally encountered in places where they have been enslaved to serve as guardians by powerful Magic-users or Chaotic Clerics. The more intelligent varieties might also be interrupted while carrying out plots of their own. There is no meaningful game distinction between demons and devils.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Demon, baalroch
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 2 [17] Hit Dice: 9 Attacks: Sword or whip (2d6) Special: See below Move: 6/15 (when flying) HDE/XP: 10/1,400
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The Baalroch's name means, roughly, the Bull of Baal: the Baal-aurochs (the aurochs was a bull that stood twelve feet tall at the shoulder, and Baal is an ancient and evil pagan deity). These powerful demons somewhat resemble vast minotaurs with great, spreading bat-wings; they burn with the fires of hell and are wreathed in flame. The spells of casters below 6th level do not affect them, and against higher-level spell casters they are yet 75% immune to all spells. In combat, a Baalroch uses whip and sword; the whip can be used to reach great distances-on a successful hit the victim is pulled close to the Baalroch and burned by the fires of the demon's body (3d6 damage). Baalrochs are sometimes referred to in ancient texts as Balor or Baalor, which may be the name of a single demon rather than a term for all of them. A Baalroch could be forced or tricked into the service of a powerful wizard, but the risk would be immense.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Demon, lemure
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 7 [12] Hit Dice: 3 Attacks: Claw Special: Regenerate (1 HP/round) Move: 3 HDE/XP: 4/120
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Lemures are vaguely humanoid-their flesh is mud-like, shifting and soft upon their horrible bodies. Like manes and wretches, lemures are lower forms of demons, the fleshly manifestations of damned souls. These demons can only be permanently destroyed by sprinkling their disgusting bodies with holy water.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: monSterS - 83
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Djinni
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Armor Class: 5 [14] Hit Dice: 7+1 Attacks: Fist or weapon (2d6) Special: See below Move: 9/24 (when flying) HDE/XP: 9/1,100
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Djinn are one of the genies of folklore, creatures of the air (and possibly of the elemental planes). They can carry 700 pounds of weight, and have a number of magical powers. A djinni can create food and water of high quality, as well as wooden and cloth objects. They can also create objects of metal (including coins), but all such magically created metals disappear in time. Djinn can call up illusions, and although these are quite excellent they disappear when touched. Djinni can turn themselves into gaseous form (cannot attack or be attacked, can enter any area that is not airtight), and can become invisible at will. Finally, a djinni can turn itself into a whirlwind much like an air elemental, sweeping away any creature with one or fewer hit dice (the diameter of the whirlwind is 10 feet). More powerful types of djinn might be capable of granting limited wishes or even true wishes.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: A doppelganger can change its form to resemble the physical appearance (including clothing and gear) of any person. These creatures are immune to sleep and charm, and are considered magic resistant for purposes such as breaking through wizard locks and similar spells. They have a very good saving throw (+5) against magic of all kinds.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 84 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Dragons
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: All dragons have a breath weapon of some kind, which can be used up to three times in a day. The Referee chooses when a dragon will use the breath weapon or may roll for it (50% chance) in any given round.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Referees should not roll for a dragon's hit points, like one would for other monsters. Instead, determine the age category of the dragon-this will give both the dragon's hit points per hit dice and how many points of breath weapon damage per hit dice the dragon inflicts.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Dragon Age Category
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Dragon Breath Weapons
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: * The dimensions of a dragon's breath differ according to the dragon's type. For example, an "Adult" dragon has both 4 hit points and 4 points of breath weapon damage per hit dice. So an "Adult" black dragon with 6 HD would have 24 HP and deal 24 points of acid damage when using its breath weapon.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: monSterS - 85
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Note that dragons, while dangerous opponents, are not by any means invincible. In a medieval-type fantasy world, dragons are a common problem rather than a godlike creature of legend-so the statistics for dragons reflect a deadly but not mythical foe. The Referee is, of course, free to create stats for a more "mythical" conception of dragons. Since dice aren't rolled for dragon hit points, it is possible for a truly mythical dragon to have more "numbers" per die than it's actually possible to roll on a hit dice.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Black dragons spit a deadly, corrosive acid rather than a breath of fire. The acid covers everything in a line 5 feet wide and 60 feet long.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Blue dragons spit a blast of electric lightning, affecting everything in its path, in a line 5 feet wide and 100 feet long. A successful saving throw against the blast of lightning indicates half damage.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Dragon, golD
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 2 [17] Hit Dice: 10-12 Attacks: Bite Special: Breathes poisonous gas or fire Move: 12/24 (when flying) HDE/XP: 12/2,000; 13/2,300; 14/2,600
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Gold dragons are of lawful alignment, can always speak, and cast spells as if they were a Magic-user of equal level to their age category (so that "Very Old" gold dragons are 6th level Magic-users). They can choose to either breathe fire in a cone 90 feet long and roughly 30 feet wide at the base or breathe chlorine gas in a cloud 50 feet in diameter.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 86 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Dragon, green
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 2 [17] Hit Dice: 7-9 Attacks: Bite Special: Breathes poisonous gas Move: 12/24 (when flying) HDE/XP: 9/1,100; 10/1,400; 11/1,700
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Green dragons breathe a cloud of poisonous gas that is 50 feet in diameter. A successful saving throw indicates half damage.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Dragon, reD
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 2 [17] Hit Dice: 9-11 Attacks: Bite Special: Breathes fire Move: 12/24 (when flying) HDE/XP: 11/1,700; 12/2,000; 13/2,300
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Red dragons are the fire-breathing wyrms of legend. They breathe fire in a cone-shape 90 feet long and roughly 30 feet wide at the base.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Dragon, white
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Armor Class: 2 [17] Hit Dice: 5-7 Attacks: Bite Special: Breathes cold Move: 12/24 (when flying) HDE/XP: 7/600; 8/800; 9/1,100
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: White dragons are usually found in cold regions, where they can utilize their natural camouflage in the ice and snow to ambush their prey. They breathe intensely cold air and frost in a cone shape 70 feet long and roughly 30 feet wide at the base.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: monSterS - 87
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: DryaD
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 5 [14] Hit Dice: 2 Attacks: Dagger, wooden Special: Charm Person Move: 12 HDE/XP: 3/60
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Dryads are beautiful female tree spirits, and do not venture far from their home trees. They can cast (as a native magical power) a strong charm that operates as a Charm Person spell with a -2 saving throw. Those who are charmed seldom return, or might be kept for a hundred years and a day within the dryad's tree.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Dwarf
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 4 [15] Hit Dice: 1+1 Attacks: War Hammer Special: Stonework insight Move: 6 HDE/XP: 1/15
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Statistics above are for the common Dwarf with no particular unusual characteristics. A Dwarf-at-arms would usually have a full 7 HP, reflecting skill and general toughness. Stronger Dwarves (sergeants-atarms, for example) might have more hit dice or unusual bonuses "to-hit", even magical abilities if Dwarves are magical in your fantasy universe. (Norse myths are a
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: good example of this.) Do not bother to treat more powerful NPC Dwarves as Fighters or character types; just assign the right number of HD and abilities (if any) and keep moving along with the fantasy.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: efreeti
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 3 [16] Hit Dice: 10 Attacks: Fist or sword (2d6) Special: Wall of Fire Move: 9/24 (when flying) HDE/XP: 12/2,000
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Efreet are a type of genie, associated with fire (unlike the djinn, who have powers over the air). Efreet can carry up to a thousand pounds of weight, and under the right circumstances they can be forced into servitude (until they figure out how to free themselves). An efreeti can cast Wall of Fire. They appear as giant humans with cruel features, their skin flickering with flames.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 88 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Elementals
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Elementals are living manifestations of the basic forms of matter; earth, air, fire, and water. They are usually summoned from their native planes of existence to do the bidding of a powerful wizard. These beings can also be "chained" within objects or structures to give the objects magical properties. Elementals are barely intelligent at all, but they are as powerful as the forces of nature that they actually are.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: elemental, air
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 2 [17] Hit Dice: 8, 12, 16 Attacks: Strike (2d6) Special: Whirlwind Move: 36 (when flying) HDE/XP: 9/1,100; 13/2,300; 17/3,400
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Air elementals can turn into a whirlwind of air with a diameter of 30 feet, hurling any creature of 1 HD or less for great distances (almost certainly killing them). Elemental whirlwinds are approximately 100 feet tall.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: elemental, earth
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 2 [17] Hit Dice: 8, 12, 16 Attacks: Fist (2d6) Special: Stone destruction Move: 6 HDE/XP: 9/1,100; 13/2,300; 17/3,400
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Earth elementals are hulking man-shapes of rock and earth. They batter opponents with their great fists, although damage is reduced by 1d6 if the opponent is not standing upon earth or rock. Earth elementals can tear apart stone structures, able to rip down even a castle wall in a matter of 1d4+4 minutes.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: elemental, fire
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 2 [17] Hit Dice: 8, 12, 16 Attacks: Strike (2d6) Special: Ignite materials Move: 12 HDE/XP: 9/1,100; 13/2,300; 17/3,400
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Fire elementals are formless masses of flame, perhaps with a vaguely human shape. Their attacks cause flammable materials to ignite if the material fails a saving throw (as determined by the Referee).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: monSterS - 89
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: elemental, water
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 2 [17] Hit Dice: 8, 12, 16 Attacks: Strike (2d6) Special: Overturn ships Move: 6/18 (when swimming) HDE/XP: 9/1,100; 13/2,300; 17/3,400
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Water elementals cannot move more than 60 feet from a large body of water, and their damage is reduced by 1d6 if the opponent is not standing (or in) a body of water. These powerful beings can overturn small boats, and can overturn a ship if given 1d4+4 minutes to work at it. On water, they can attack ships, battering them to pieces within one hour if not prevented or distracted.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The example above is for a typical Elf; trained warriors would likely have the maximum 7 HP. Obviously, Elves encountered in the course of a party's adventuring will have a variety of powers and different attributes. The Referee will assign such powers as they see fit, in accordance with the way they envision Elves. Elves might be the woodland dwellers of Tolkien's The Hobbit, or the high Elves of the Lord of the Rings, or might be the faerie-folk of Irish legend. In any case, as with Dwarves, don't bother trying to fit your "advanced" elves into the constraints of character classes-just make up their attributes to fit what you need. NPCs aren't subject to the rules that govern building a player character; they are your tools for good fantasy, not an exercise in formula application.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Gargoyles are winged creatures resembling the carved monstrosities that bedeck the walls of cathedrals and many subterranean dungeons. They can be vicious predators.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 90 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: gelatinouS cube
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 8 [11] Hit Dice: 4 Attacks: Strike Special: See below Move: 6 HDE/XP: 5/240
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Gelatinous cubes are semi-transparent cubes that slosh through subterranean passages, engulfing debris and
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: carrion to digest. Their entire substance is acidic: if the cube hits successfully, the victim must make a saving throw or become paralyzed (6 turns)-during which time the cube will attempt to devour its victim. Most gelatinous cubes contain various metallic treasures or gems that they have engulfed but not yet digested. Gelatinous cubes are immune to lightning and cold.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Ghouls are pack-hunting undead, corpse eaters. They are immune, like most undead, to charms and sleep spells. The most dangerous feature of these horrid, cunning creatures is their paralyzing touch: any hit from a ghoul requires a saving throw or the victim becomes paralyzed for 3d6 turns.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Giants
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Giants are a staple of fantasy gaming, huge and dangerous creatures that often have a taste for human flesh. Most are not particularly intelligent.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: giant, clouD
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 4 [15] Hit Dice: 12+2 Attacks: Weapon (3d6) Special: Hurls boulders Move: 15 HDE/XP: 13/2,300
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Cloud giants are cunning beasts, often living in cloud-castles in the sky (hence their name). They throw rocks for 6d6 hit points of damage. Cloud giants are famous for their ability to smell out food, enemies, and Englishmen.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: monSterS - 91
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: giant, fire
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 4 [15] Hit Dice: 11+3 Attacks: Weapon (2d6) Special: Hurls boulders, fire immunity Move: 12 HDE/XP: 12/2,000
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Fire giants are usually found near volcanic mountains, in great castles of basalt or even iron. They throw boulders for 5d6 hit points and are immune to fire.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: giant, froSt
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 4 [15] Hit Dice: 10+1 Attacks: Weapon (2d6) Special: Hurls boulders, cold immunity Move: 12 HDE/XP: 12/2,000
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Frost giants dwell in cold regions, where they build (or conquer) castles in remote places of ice and snow. They throw boulders or great chunks of ice for 4d6 points of damage and are immune to cold.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: giant, hill
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 4 [15] Hit Dice: 8 Attacks: Weapon (2d6) Special: Hurls boulders Move: 12 HDE/XP: 9/1,100
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Hill giants are the least of the giant types; most are brutish cave-dwellers who dress in pelts and uncured hides. They throw rocks for 2d8 points of damage.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: giant, Stone
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 4 [15] Hit Dice: 9 Attacks: Club (2d6) Special: Hurls boulders Move: 12 HDE/XP: 10/1,400
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 92 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Stone giants dwell in caves, isolated in the mountain fastness. They throw rocks for 3d6 points of damage, and can be quite crafty in setting up ambushes in their native mountains-travelers who wander into the territory of stone giants seldom return.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: giant, Storm
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 1 [18] Hit Dice: 16 Attacks: Weapon (3d6) Special: See below Move: 15 HDE/XP: 16/3,200
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Storm giants are the largest of giants, the most intelligent, the most magical, and the most likely to talk with humans rather than simply devour them. Storm giants can live in underwater sea-castles as well as on the heights of mountains. They throw boulders for 7d6 points of damage, and have the power to cast Control Weather.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Gnolls are tall humanoids with hyena-like heads. They may be found both above ground and in subterranean caverns. They form into loosely organized clans, often ranging far from home to steal and kill with rapacious ferocity.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: goblin
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 6 [13] Hit Dice: 1-1 Attacks: Weapon Special: -1 "to-hit" in sunlight Move: 9 HDE/XP: < 1/10
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Goblins are small creatures (4 feet tall or so) that inhabit dark woods, underground caverns, and (possibly) the otherworldly realms of the fey. They attack with a -1 "to-hit" in the full sunlight.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: monSterS - 93
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Golems
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Golems are man-shaped creatures built to serve their masters, usually powerful wizards or high priests. They are often used as guardians. Golems cannot be hit with non-magical weapons, and are immune to the sorts of spells used to create them (iron golems being immune to fire, for instance). You can find the details in the specific monster descriptions.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: golem, fleSh
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 9 [10] Hit Dice: 12 Attacks: Fist Special: See below Move: 8 HDE/XP: 12/2,000
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: A creation stitched together from human limbs and other parts, like Frankenstein's monster. Damage inflicted by lightning heals the golem, and it is slowed by fire and cold. No other type of spell than lightning, fire, or cold affects a flesh golem. Only +1 or better magic weapons can harm a flesh golem.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: golem, iron
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 3 [16] Hit Dice: 13 Attacks: Fist or weapon Special: See below Move: 6 HDE/XP: 17/3,500
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Iron golems are huge moving statues of iron. They can breathe a 10 foot radius cloud of poison gas as well as attacking with great power. Only +3 or better magic weapons can harm an iron golem. These hulking statues are slowed by lightning spells, but fire-based spells actually restore hit points to them. No other type of spell affects them.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 94 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Stone golems are massive stone statues animated by very powerful magics (much more than just animate object, in other words). They are slowed by fire spells, and damaged/healed by rock to mud spells and the reverse. Spells that affect rock (and fire spells) are the only magic that affects them. They can only be hit by weapons +2 or better.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Gorgons are bull-like creatures with dragon-like scales. Their breath turns people to stone (60 foot range, saving throw applies).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Grey ooze is almost identical to wet rock, but is a slimy, formless substance that devours prey and carrion with its acidic secretions, lashing forward to strike enemies. Grey ooze is immune to spells, heat, and cold damage. Metal (but not stone or wood) must make a saving throw vs. acid when exposed to grey ooze (even if the contact is as brief as the strike of a sword) or be rotted through. When the grey ooze hits a character in metal armor, the armor must make an item saving throw. Only cutting and piercing damages a grey ooze- it is impervious to blunt or crushing attacks.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: green Slime
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Green slime isn't technically a monster, just an extremely dangerous hazard in underground tombs and other such places. Any metal or organic substance it touches begins to turn to green slime (saving throw). It can be killed with fire or extreme cold, and the transformation process can be arrested by the use of the spell Cure Disease.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: monSterS - 95
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: griffon
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 3 [16] Hit Dice: 7 Attacks: Bite Special: Flight Move: 12/27 (when flying) HDE/XP: 8/800
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Griffons have the body of a lion, with the wings, head, and fore-talons of an eagle. These creatures can be tamed and ridden as mounts. They usually nest in high mountain aeries, where they lay their eggs and hunt their prey. Because the fledglings can be tamed, young griffons and griffon eggs command a very high price in the marketplaces of the great cities, or to barons and wizards.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Harpies have the upper body of a human female and the lower body and wings of a vulture. Their song is a charm that draws its victims to the harpy (saving throw applies), and the harpy's touch casts the equivalent of a Charm Person spell (again, saving throw applies).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: hell hounD
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 4 [15] Hit Dice: 4-7 Attacks: Bite Special: Breathes fire Move: 12 HDE/XP: 5/240; 6/400; 7/600; 8/800
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Hell hounds are fire-breathing dogs of the underworlds or lower planes. In addition to biting, they can breathe fire each round, inflicting 2 HP damage per hit die (10 foot range, saving throw for half damage).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 96 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: hippogriff
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 5 [14] Hit Dice: 3+1 Attacks: Claws Special: Flight Move: 12/27 (when flying) HDE/XP: 3/60
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The hippogriff is similar to a griffon, having the head, foreclaws, and wings of an eagle, but instead of the body of a lion, it has the body of a horse. The poem Orlando Furioso (written in 1516) suggests that the hippogriff is the offspring of a griffon and a horse-but they are apparently an independent breed, for folkloric tradition holds that griffons frequently attack hippogriffs. Hippogriffs are not as hard to train
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: as griffons-again, from Orlando Furioso: "Drawn by enchantment from his distant lair, The wizard thought but how to tame the foal; And, in a month, instructed him to bear Saddle and bit, and gallop to the goal; And execute on earth or in mid air, All shifts of manege, course and caracoleâ¦"
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: hobgoblin
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Hobgoblins are simply large goblins, possibly a separate breed living apart from their smaller cousins. As a matter of the campaign's flavoring, the Referee might choose to make hobgoblins the "fey" goblins of Irish legend, while regular goblins are the more Tolkien-style underground-dwellers.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: horSe
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Horses are AC 7 [12], with riding horses having 2 HD and warhorses having 3 HD. Horses move at a speed of 18.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: monSterS - 97
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Humans
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Humans are such a versatile species that any number of "monsters" and NPCs can be made from them. Berserker warriors, tribesmen, cavemen, princesses, evil high priests, captains of the guard, foot-soldiers, and tavern-keepers are all different human "monsters."
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Don't try to build your non-player characters according to the rules for player characters. Here are some samples, otherwise just make up their stats and abilities as you see fit.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: human, banDit
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 7 [12] Hit Dice: 1 Attacks: Weapon Special: None Move: 12 HDE/XP: 1/15
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Bandits are roving groups of thieves, sometimes organized into small armies led by more powerful bandit chiefs and captains with higher hit dice.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: human, berSerker
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 7 [12] Hit Dice: 1+2 Attacks: Weapon Special: Berserking Move: 12 HDE/XP: 2/30
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Berserkers are normal humans, but they fight with astounding ferocity. A bonus of +2 is added to their attack rolls. They do not wear armor heavier than leather armor.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: human, Sergeant-at-armS
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 5 [14] Hit Dice: 3 Attacks: Weapon Special: None Move: 12 HDE/XP: 3/60
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 98 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Human sergeants are normally found in command of 1d6+5 human soldiers. These are the leaders of city guard units and other small military groups in castles and armies.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Human soldiers serve as city guardsmen, mercenaries, and men-at-arms. They are generally armed with leather armor and a mace, sword, or spear. For every five guardsmen there is usually a sergeant.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: hyDra
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 5 [14] Hit Dice: 5-12 (equals # of heads) Attacks: 5-12 bites Special: See below Move: 9 HDE/XP: 7/600; 8/800; 9/1,100; 10/1,400; 11/1,700; 12/2,000
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Hydrae are great lizard-like or snake-like creatures with 5-12 heads. Each head has one hit die of its own, and when the head is killed, that head dies. The body has as many hit dice as the total of the heads, so it is a matter of good strategy for adventurers to focus either on killing heads (when all the heads are dead the body dies) or killing the creature by attacking the body (in which case the heads die, too). Hydrae that breathe fire or regenerate their heads are known to exist.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: inviSible Stalker
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 3 [16] Hit Dice: 8 Attacks: Bite Special: Flight, invisibility Move: 12 HDE/XP: 9/1,100
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Invisible stalkers are generally only found as a result of the spell Invisible Stalker. They are invisible flying beings created to follow a single command made by the caster.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: monSterS - 99
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: kobolD
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 6 [13] Hit Dice: 1/2 Attacks: Weapon Special: None Move: 6 HDE/XP: < 1/10
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Kobolds are subterranean, vaguely goblin-like humanoids. They have a -1 "tohit" penalty when fighting above ground. Many use slings or short bows, and they fight with short swords or spiked clubs in melee combat.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: lich Armor Class: 0 [19] Hit Dice: 12-18 Attacks: Touch Special: See below Move: 6 HDE/XP: 15/2,900; 16/3,200; 17/3,500; 18/3,800; 19/4,100; 20/4,400; 21/4,700
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Liches are the undead remnants of wizards, either made undead by their own deliberate acts during life or as the result of other magical forces (possibly including their own magics gone awry). A lich has the same spell-casting powers as the original Magic-user (the same level as the lich's HD). A lich's touch causes paralysis with no saving throw, and the very sight of one of these dread creatures causes paralysis in any being of 4 HD or below. Liches are highly malign and intelligent.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Lizardmen are reptilian humanoids, usually living in tribal villages in the depths of fetid swamps. Some can hold their breath for a long duration (an hour or more), while others can actually breathe underwater. Some lizardmen wield a wicked sword made of sharp bone.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 100 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Lycanthropes
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Lycanthropes are were-creatures, particularly those in whom the disease permits assumption of a hybrid form of the human and animal. They cannot be hit by normal weapons; only silver or magical weapons inflict damage on them. If any character is brought lower than 50% hit points by a lycanthrope, the character will be infected with lycanthropy.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: lycanthrope, werebear
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 2 [17] Hit Dice: 7+3 Attacks: Bite Special: Lycanthropy Move: 9 HDE/XP: 8/800
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Werebears are often found in temperate forests.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: lycanthrope, wererat
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 6 [13] Hit Dice: 3 Attacks: Weapon Special: Control rats, lycanthropy Move: 12 HDE/XP: 4/120
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Wererats are mostly found in cities, lurking in shadowy alleyways. Wererats can control rats, and are extremely stealthy (surprising opponents 1-4 on a d6).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: lycanthrope, werewolf
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 5 [14] Hit Dice: 3 Attacks: Bite or Claw Special: Lycanthropy Move: 12 HDE/XP: 4/120
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Werewolves are the traditional Lycanthropes seen in horror movies. They are often only affected by silver or magical weapons, and are often humanoid- except for during a full moon, and so on.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: monSterS - 101
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: manticore
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 4 [15] Hit Dice: 6+4 Attacks: Tail-spikes Special: Flight Move: 12/8(when flying) HDE/XP: 8/800
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: A horrid monster with bat wings, the face of a feral human, the body of a lion, and a tail tipped with 24 iron spikes. The manticore can hurl up to 6 of the iron spikes from its tail per round, at a maximum range of 180 feet.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Medusae are horrid creatures from Greek mythology with a female face but hair of writhing snakes; they have no legs, but the body of a serpent. The gaze of a medusa turns anyone looking upon it into stone. In addition to the medusa's relatively weak melee-weapon attack, the snake-hair makes one attack per round, causing no damage but lethally poisonous with a successful hit (saving throw applies).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: minotaur
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 6 [13] Hit Dice: 6+4 Attacks: Weapon Special: Never lost in labyrinths Move: 12 HDE/XP: 6/400
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The minotaur is a man-eating predator from Greek mythology, with the head of a bull and the body of a massive human, covered in shaggy hair. Sometimes they wield large axes and most are not particularly intelligent.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 102 - SwordS & wizardry white Box ruleS
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: mummy
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Armor Class: 3 [16]
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Hit Dice: 5+1
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Attacks: Touch (See below)
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Special: See below
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Move: 6
main-text.name: Text
